The tenement house in the rear of Mr. MCKEVITT'S, No. 16 Fifth-street, was the scene last night of a shocking murder and suicide. The parties concerned in this sad tragedy were WILLIAM and THOMAS BOOTH, brothers, who occupied adjacent tenements.

Since I last wrote we have had unusually dull times in this city. Even the roughs seem to have somewhat subsided since our Recorder gave their associates such a handling at the close of the January Term.

Yesterday was remarkable as being the coldest day during the Winter thus far. The lowest point reached by the mercury in the moment was 11 degree above zero about sunrise; at 3 P. M. it marked 25 degree; at 11 P. M., 21 degree. The barometrical record at 7 A. M. was 30.03 inches; at 3 P. M., 29.99 inches; at 11 P. M., 29.96 inches.

When the Court of Oyer and Terminer convened yesterday morning to proceed with the rial of JOHN REYNOLDS, there was an agreeable prospect, which the event amply Justified, that the day would not be marred by the scenes of semi-disorder in the Court room which had marked the previous day.

Additional testimony was taken in the case of MARTIN R. COOK, a wholesale liquor dealer, and E. B. FARRINGTON, jointly charged with conspiracy to defraud the Government of the tax on about one thousand gallons of whisky, in the United States Commissiouer's offices yesterday. District-Attorney PIERREPONT conducted the examination for the Government.

A dispatch rom Halifax to the Daily Telegraph says the troop ship Onontes, which left Halifax for England two days before the City of Boston, arrived after a passage of twelve days. She encountered fearful weather.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Some days since all article appeared in your journal that would seem to institute that either Mr. FISK or myself had some instrumentality in the recent assault on Mr. EATON, AS MR. EATON himself, in an interview with the managing editor of the New-York Sun,

The Republican State Convention that has just adjourned was the largest and most enthusiastic one ever hold in this State, over seventeen hundred delegates, representing every county in the State, being present. At 2 o'clock the Academy of Music, large as it is, proved insufficient to accommodate the vast concourse.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: "The bill for the preservation of the harbors of the United States against encroachments was taken up. Mr. STOCKTON, (Dem.,) of New-Jersey, opposed the bill as unconstitutional, and asked it be laid aside for the present.

The examination in the case of WILLIAM M. FLEISS, a wholesale liquor dealer, of Nos. 77 and 79 Broad-street, charged with having made false income returns, was resumed before Commissioner OSBORN yesterday. The proceedings were instituted by Collector BAILEY.

Mr. BURLINGAME died at St. Petersburg shortly before noon to-day, of congestion of the lungs. The deepest sympathy is felt for his family. The Emperor and Empress of Russia have sent letters of condolence to the widow of the deceased.

ROBERT HINES, a painter, residing at No. 569 Second-avenue, was arrangned at the Essex Market Police Court, yesterday, before Justice LEDWITH, charged with breaking into the premises of FRANCIS KEATING, No. 307 First-avenu on Tuesday evening, and firmg a loaded revolver at FRANCIS J. KEATING, Jp., with intent to kill.

In the Mordaunt divorce ease to-day, the Prince of WALES, some of whose letters to Lady MORDAUNT have been published, was called to the witness stand. Lord PENZANCE pointed out that no witness was bound to make to any question an answer which would admit that he had been guilty of adultery.

Masquerades were held by two of the German Singing societies of this City last night, in which the members of the societies and their friends participated. The "Mozart Maennerchor," Mr. JACOB GREGORIUS President, and MIr. CHARLLS KORFF, Musical Director,

The following appears to be real state of the case, according to the a will, bequeathing his entire estate to his excentor, ALBERT DAY, of this City, in trust for the Cooper Union.

It is sad enough to feel that a great statesmen lies dead in the foreign capital of Russia. What an evidence of tile vanity of human wishes in the spectacle of this splendid Embassy, representing the oldest and most populous Government of tile worldentering upon the hospitalitoes of welcoming Russia, only to find its illustrious chief stricken with death!

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Perhaps the reason the World declines to publish the names of the "Judges who sell injustice for a price" is because they are already se well known. Were it to answer, it would doubt less say that it there is any one still so ignorant as not to know, he need only consult the publicly-expressed opinion of the streets, and particularly of the legal profession,

In steamship City of Cork, for Liverpool,--Miss Carmichael, Mrs. Longmaid, 5 children and servant, Colonel and Mrs. Francklyn, Saml. L. Cutter, J. R. Carmichael, Mr. Jno. C. Lendin, Wm. Gilbert M. B. Daily, S. B. McDonald, G. W. Smith, Mrs. McKay and infant, Miss Finnister Miss Jennie Finnister.

Rumors were circulated in Jersey City yesterday that some notable changes were taking place or were about to take place among the Erie Railway officials. According to the reports, Superintendent RUCKERT was about to be suspended, as well as the Chief Engineer.

The Real Estate Exchange presented a lively appearance yesterday, the large room being entirely filled with gentlemen who had been attracted thither by the announcements of important sales by several of the leading auctioneers of the place.

Messrs. POMEROY and ANTHONY presented petitions for extending the suffrage to women. ALASKA. Mr. HOWARD, from the Committee on Territories, reported with amendments the bill for a territorial form of government for Alaska.

A social club, composed of the leading political and business men of Harlem, has recently been organized under the above name. The following are the officers: President, JOHN HALLORAN; Vice-President, ARCHIBALD PHILIPS; Secretaries, JAMES SEBERRY. WM. WELCH; Treasurer, FRANK KING.

The tidings of the death of Hon. ANSON BURLINGAME at St. Petersburg, yesterday, where he had just arrived with his associates of the Chinese Embassy, were received in the City with aniversal surprise and regret. The particulars of the unexpected event thus far received are meagre. It is only known that he died of congestion of the lungs after a very short illness.

Commissioner BETTS took more testimony yesterday in the case of MARTIN R. COOK, of the firm of GORDON, FOLLOWS McMILLAN, wholesale liquor dealers, and E. B. FARRINGTON, an ex-gauger, jointly charged with conspiring to defraud the Government of the tax on a large amount of whisky. District-Attorney PIERREPONT conducted the examination.

The new steamship City of Merida, built by Messrs. JOHN ENGLIS SON, was successfully launched from their shipyard at Greenpoint yesterday afternoon. The launch was witnessed by about 5,000 people, and was the occasion of much enthusiasm. The new steamer is designed to form one of the Havana and Mexican line of Messrs. T. ALEXANDRE SONS.

Captains and pursers of vessels arriving at this port are requested to deliver packages addressed to the New-York Associated Press, only to parties exhibiting the written authority of J. W. Simonton, General Agent.

The regular monthly sale of Scranton coal was held yesterday by Messrs. J. H. DRAPER Co., auctioneers. There was a large attendance of buyers, and the bidding was spirited. The following lots were disposed of and prices realized:

A letter from Fort Sully gives particulars of a desperate fight bebetween three hundred Sioux and Crow Indians early in January, above the mouth of the Yellowstone, on the Missouri River. The attack was made near sundown, under the Chief, Spotted Eagle, who was killed.

The steamer just arrived brings another excellent number of the Graphic, with a charming picture of two children reading their" first valentine," another of "St. Valentino's Day," and a third representing " Kabyle Orange Sellers In Algiers." Each one is a beautiful specimen of wood engraving.

The extraordinary and unprecedented action of Police Justice BUCKLEY, of Brooklyn, on Monday last, in releasing the proprietors of the " swill milk" establishments who were brought before him for trial, on the grounds, as he stated, " that there was no public prosecutor present,"

When CUSTER, last year, moved against Black Kettle and the Cheyenncs,destroying the camp of that thieving band with great slaughter, we defended and applauded the affair, because the offence had been greater even than the penalty.

Tho New-York Liberal Club hold its regular weekly meeting, last evening, at No. 23 Third-avenue, Mr. HENRY WEIILE, President, in the chair. Professor GEORGE BATCHELOR read an interesting paper on Polyglotism.

The Board of Health met yesterday at the casual hour, President GEORGE B. LINCOLN in the chair. The usual routine business from the attorney's office was presented and passed upon, but furnished nothing of general interest. A communication was received from

After the very complete account of the two days' disturbances in Paris supplied by our correspondent and printed in the TIMES of Tuesday, no additional reports are needed. We supplement the published story, however, with a translation of M. GUSTAVE FLOURENS' summary of the earliest incidents of the outbreak, published over his signature in La Refome newspaper.

The following letter, addressed to the members of both branches of the Legislature, was sent to Albany yesterday be the Association of this City: THE CITIZENS' ASSOCIATION OF NEW-YORK, NO. 813 BROADWAY, Feb. 21. 1870. The Honorable the members of the Senate and Assembly of the State of New-York:

BOSWORTH--NEWBOULD.--On Wednesday, Feb, 23, at the Chapel of the Holy Saviour, by Rev. A. B. Carter, CHARLES H. BOSWORTH to CHELLA, daughter of Thomas M. Newbould, all of this City. CAVILEER--QUERIPEL,--In New-York, on Wednesday, Jan. 26, at the residence of the bride's father, by Rev. A. D. Vall, of the M. E. Church, Captain FESSE R. CAVILEER, of Lower Bank, N. J., to SARHA. QUERIPEL, of New-York City.

We have no tidings as yet of the steamship City of Boston, which left Halifax for Liverpool on the 28th ult., and has not since been heard from. We are informed by the agent of the Inman line that the passengers, of whom we gave a list in Wednesday's TIMES as having sailed from this City to Europe in the City of Boston , did not go further than Halifax.

The scene at tho House, to-day, brought back mildly the days of impeachment. No such intense interest, or vast audience has boon either felt or witnessed since that memorable occasion. Promptly at 2 o'clock the House proceeded to the consideration of the case of Mr. WHITTEMORE. It was known yesterday that
The steamship Rapidan, which left Havana Feb. 15, reached this port yesterday. Purser OSCAR CROCHERON has our thanks for the prompt delivery of our Cuban files and correspondence.

Mayor PRICE, of Mobile, to-day applied to the Supreme Court for a writ of supersedeas to release himself from jail and have the recent act of the Legislature passed on by the Court. One of the Judges refused the wit, the effect of which is to instal HARRINGTON, the recently appointed Mayor, over PRICE.

Yesterday a fair and festival were held at the Orphans' Home and Asylum of the Protestant Episcopal Church in Forty-ninth-street. A very large number of visitors were present during the day, and the fair was well patronised. The children, about 144 in number, assembled in their school rooms and amused themselves by singing , recitations and various games.

The Cunard steamship Calabria, which loft Liverpool Feb. 12 and Queenstown Feb. 13, reached this port late Tuesday night. Her advices are later by two days than wore those received by the City of Brooklyn. The death is announced of Sir HUGH BATES MAXWELL, Baronet, a member of a knightly family, and one of the most ancient in Scotland, one HERBERT DE MACCUSVILLE having assumed the name of MAXWELL in the time or MALCOLM IV.
The Special Committee of the Common Council appointed to tender to Hon. WM. H. SEWARD a public reception on his arrival in this City, met at noon yesterday, Alderman MILLER in the chair.

A convention of those interested in the various interests of the tobacco trade residing in various sections of the Union, was held at Steinway Hall, yesterday afternoon t 2 o'clock. The attendance was very large. The object of the gathering was to urge upon Congress the necessity of making such amendments to the Internal Revenue law as shall remedy the unequal and alleged oppressive bearing of that law upon the tobacco trade.

The Senate met at 7:30 P. M. BILLS INTRODUCED. By Mr. WOODIN-Amending the Auburn Water Works Company charter; ordered to a third reading; also, amending the act fixing the fees of Justices of the Peace and constables in civil and criminal cases, and of Jurors and witnesses in Justices' Courts.

The sixth annual reunion of the " A. 0. E." Society of Bellevue Hospital MedicalCollege took place last evening in the hall of the institution, which was filled to overflowing with ladies and gentlemen, friends and relatives of the students. The exercises consisted of addresses by the President. Dr. Harwood.

A bill was introduced in the House to incorporate the Paterson and New-York Railroad Company, with authority to construct a road from Paterson to any point on the Hudson River within the County of Hudson. The capital is fixed at $1, 000,000.

The French Republicans resident in this City and the vicinity, to the number of six or seven hundred. met last night to celecbratc, by a banquet at the Union Assembly Rooms, the anniversary of the French Revolution of 1848. M. CHARLES VILLA presided, supported on the right by General CLUSERET, the well known socialist, and on the left by M. C. PELLETIER, representative of Lyons in 1848.

The moderated temperature of yesterday again spoiled skating propects. Neither the Central Park Popd, nor MAC MILLAN'S, nor the Brooklyn Rinks were solid enough to be opened all day to the public. The Empire Rink was patronized, but the crowd on Tuesday had hurt the surface.

A meeting of the citizens of Mount Vernon of East Chester, was held last evening to take action with reference to the proposed tax to be assessed in order to cover the expenses incident to the construction of a boulevard through a portion of the town.

In the Methodist State Convention to-day, Rev. Dr. PECK, of Albany, from the Committee on the subject, submitted a paper which, under the heading of "Our Position," holds as follows: First, we propose to speak and act, not as church men, but as free American citizens: second, we ask no peculiar privileges for our own Church, we will concede none to any other; third, we demand equali.

The Prince of WALES was yesterday examined as a witness in the Mordauut divorce suit, and testified that "there never had been any improper or criminal intention between himself and Lady MORDAUNT." The declaration was received with cheers by the spectators.... A Paris dispatch says that Don CARLOS was arrested at Lyons while traveling in the South of France in violation of one of the conditions of his permission to remaining France.

The receptions yesterday at Mr. DE GAnMO'S Dancing Academy, No. 82 Fifth-avenue, were brilliant affairs, and numerously attended by his friends, patrons and pupils. At the malinee in the afternoon a variety of new dances were introduced for the first time, accompanied with new music. The third dance on the programme was a galop, composed by WIEGAND,

At a late hour last night a woman with an infant in her arms appeared at the Station House in Jersey City and asked for a night's lodging. She was of respectable appearance, and gave her name as CATIIARINE SINCLAIR. She stated, in reply to inquiries, that she had been married to JOHN SINCLAIR, at present an employee in the sugar works, for six Years:

This afternoon, at 3 o'clock, a meeting of "those who are opposed to the present unjust and intolerable tariff legislation of the country, and who favor a stricity revenue measure," will be held in the Hall of the Open Board of Brokers, No. 16 Broad-street, two doors south of the Stock Exchange.

Lord GRENVILLE has written to the Lieutenant-Governor announcing the intention of the Imperial Government to withdraw the troops in garrison in Newfoundland, and says in the future this Province will have to rely on its own protection of such as it may obtain from the Dominion of Canada, if it joins the Confederation.

JACOB HAHN, while acting in a disorderly manner yesterday in the First Ward, was ordered to desist. by Officer JoHN L. LOCKWOOD, of the Twenty-seventh Precinet. HAHN resisted arrest and presenting a loaded pistol at the breast of the patrolman, pulled the trigger. The intended murderer was thwarted in his purpose, however, for the cap failed to explode the charge.

At an early hour yesterday morning a man named EDWARD SINNETT was brought to the City Hospital with a pretty large flesh wound in his head. It has been stated that this was the result of a blow from a club, received about midnight on Tuesday evening.. The statement of the wounded man, however, makes it assume a more serious complexion.

The Commissioners of quarantine, accompanied by Messrs. Jacobs, Bergen and Banker, three of the members of the Committee on Ways and Means, Mayor Kalbfleisch, Dr. Swinburne, Dr, Anderson and Wm. A. Cobb, ex-Quarantine Commissioners;

The New-York Presbytery of the Reformed Presbyterian Church held a meeting yesterday at the Church of the Third Congregation, on West Twenty-Third-Street, for the purpose of ordaining and installing Rev. DAVID GREGG, Jr., as its pastor. The Presbytery consisted of the settled ministers of sixteen congregations and one lay member from each, and was presided over by Rev. J. W. SHAW of Coldenham.

ITALIAN OPERA. Mr. MARETZEK has determined to close his season, or rather to postpone the remaining nights of it, until after Lent. It seems that one of his attractions having failed him, he doubts the strength of those that remain to carry him through the advertised season.

A vast crowd of people again besieged the doors of the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday morning. The conviction of REYNOLDS and the knowledge that the death sentence was to be passed upon him at the approaching session bad attracted this vast and vicious appearing assemblage, who with great difficulty were prevented from overflowing the Court room.

Up to this time the quarrel in the Legislature over the reorganization of the local Government ot the City of New-York has been confined to the factions of the Democratic Party. The leaders of the ballot-box stuffers and repeating gangs have monopolized the subject of municipal government, and our citizens,--those who earn the money which pays the taxes that keep these gentlemen in affluent circumstances,--have looked on at the fight with considerable amusement.

Senator CONKLING'S speech on the Fifteenth Amendment was a good sound argument, and his onslaught upon the Now-York Democracy was very effective until he treated his audience to some "odorous comparisons." It is not easy to say whom he had in his mind when he spoke ironically of "Sextus as a vestal virgin."

A gentleman in Alleghany, Penn., broke his arm on Saturday night in pulling off his boot. The San Francisco earthquake cured a headache for OLE BULL. Governor WALKER'S Message, in relation to the finances of Virginia, will probably be communicated to the Legislature to-day.

The reception of Palastine Commandery no. 18, of knights Tempiar of this City, took place last evening at Apollo Hall. The attend ance was large, and the room was beautifully draped with banners and other insignia of the Order. The music was by BERNSTEIN'S orchestra.

CHAPMAN.-On Tuesday, Feb. 22, 1870, F. L. CHAPMAN, aged 45 years. Friends and relatives of the family are invited to attend his funeral from the First Presbyterian Church Bergen, N. J., on Friday, at 3 P. M. COOPER.-After a short illness, on Tuesday morning, ALETTA COOPER.

The Empire Skating Rink, at the corner of Third-avenue and Sixty-fourth-street, was the scene of great animation and gaiety last evening, the occasion being a fancy dress and masquerade carnival given under the auspices of the Empire City Skating Club. There was a large number of ladies and gentlemen present, including several in costume. A band of music was in attendance.

The Exchange presented a lively appearance again yesterday, and quite a large number of important sales took place. MULLER, WILKINS Co. disposed of several houses and lots, including a four-story brown-stone house on West Forty-sixth-street, between Fifth and Sixth avenues. This last excited considerable competition, and was struck down at $34,000.

The Commissioners appointed by the General conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, to confer with the representatives of other Methodist bodies in the country, which assembled in Philadelphia last November, did not then conclude their labors, and the subject matter of the Conference is still discussed in correspondence between the Bishops of the respective organizations.

The Society of the Liederkranz celebrated, after Its habitual fashion, the carnival of the present year. The record of the fact indicates in itself that a superb pageant was shown at the Academy of Music, and that the house was filled by as Joyous a throng as ever gathered within its walls.

WALLACK'S THEATRE. The performances of to-night and to-morrow afternoon will be the last for those Winter season in which Mr. LESTER WALLACK is to participate, as he loaves town directly after for an extended tour through the country. It is a fitting occasion to say a few words respecting Mr. WALLACK'S acting and the service that his management has afforded to the theatre-going public.

Coroner FLYNN decided yesterday to commence his investigation into the disaster in DECKER Co.'s factory, In West Thirty-thirdstreet, on Monday next. It will be remembered that the locomotive boiler exploded on the 14th ??st., and caused the death of WM. S. WRIGHT, one of the clerks, and severely injured JOHN DONNELIY and one or two others.
Mr. WHITTEMORE cheated the House out of its just dues to-day. Its dues were the expulsion of the inculpated member. But it was not the fault of Mr. WHITTEMORE.

Once a year it is in order, we believe, for some Congressman to take those floor with a resolution to wipe out West Point and annihilate the Naval Academy. This year the traditional task has fallen upon a new candidate for such honors,-Mr. SPECNCER, of Alabama.

Henolulu dates of Feb. 5 have been received. The hoisting of the Consular flag of Austria was witnessed by the officers of the Austrian frigate Donau, the members of the island Cabinet, all the foreign Ministers, and the entire Consular Corps. The missionary packet Morning Star was wrecked on Ibiouga Island Oct. 18. She is a total loss.

Fire last night destroyed a block on the north side of Strand, between Fremont and Twenty-scond streets, and the opposite block on the south side of Strand. Many of the houses were of little value, but were filled with large stocks of goods. The loss is estimated at $1,000.000.

The Senate Committee on Post Offices, at their meeting this morning, heard Mr. ORTON, President of the Western Union Telegraph Company, in opposition to the Hubbard bill and to the report which that Committee recently made in its favor.
The Joint Committee of the General Assemblies or the late Old and New School Presbyterian Churches, on the reconstruction of the Board of Church Extension, was in session here yesterday and to-day.

The first of a course of free lectures was delivered last evening at the reading room of the "Lord Industrial School," at No. 207 Greenwich-street, by Dr. JOHN HALL. His subject was "Knowledge and Life." The lecturer was introduced by Mr. D. EDWIN HAWLEY, Secretary of the organization, who,

A case transpired at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday which developed the circumstances of an extraordinary and determined attempt at the abduction of a female child on the part of a woman named MARY JANE DUFFY, who resides at No. 52 Ninth-avenue.

The Fat Man's reception last evening was at least obaracteristic as far as its proportions were concerned. Certainly, Irving Hall has never been more densely crowded by the fat, fair and rotund of both sexes. The arrangements for the general gratification and dilectation of the guests were ample and generous. At 10 P. M. the strains of the band proclaimed the interesting faet to the assembling pleasure-seekers that the iestivities were about to eventuate.

Quite an excitement was occasioned yesday afternoon in the Tombs Police Court by the arraignment of sixteen boys fantastically attired in a scarlet uniform, all carrying illuminated banners. The Court room soon fi11ed with spectators, and the prisoners made a dashing show as they arraigned themselves before the Magistrate. 0fficer BEATTY,

Rear-Admiral ROWAN, commanding the Asiatic Sauadron, reports to the Navy Department, under date of Hong Kong, Jan. 14, satisfactory condition of affairs on that station, so far as American Interests are concerned.

Rear Admiral ROWAN, commanding the Asiatic Squadron, informs the Navy Department, in dispatches from Hong Kong, Jan. 4, that the health of the squadron is excellent. Naval honors were paid to the memories of late Secretary of War STANTON, ex-President PIERCE and Rear-Admiral STEWART, and were joined in by the English, Italian, North German and Austrian vessels in port,

Some further testimony was taken yesterday, before Surrogate HUTCHINGS, in regard to the will of the late Mr. ADDISGTON, the particulars of which have already appeared in the TIMES. Mr. Cyrus Curlis testified that the deceased was in the employ of the institution of which he (witness) was President; that he acted as their agent for some ten months;

The Working women's protective Union of Boston has unanimously adopted the following: Resolved, That we will not become parties to any attempted encroachments on the legitimate sphere of man's duties: and, therefore we respectfully, but firmly, remonstrate against legislation in favor of suffrage for women. age for women.

There is less agitation of political topics just now than is usual at this season. The protracted vacation of Parliament leaves the public a long pause of expectation, and the newspapers are principally occupied with the discussion of questions of local and minor concern.

The following is the list of new buildings proposed since the last report, and for the week ending Thursday, Feb. 24, 1870: PUBLIC BUILDINGS. One Church, northeast corner of One Hundred and Twenty-Sixth-Street and Madison-avenue, 88x136, one story, front brown stone and brick; The Methodist Episcopal society, owner.

The presentation of diplomas to the graduates of Grammar School No. 22, situated corner of Sheriff and Stanton streets, took place yesterday afternoon. There was a large attendance of visitors, and addresses were made by RICHARD LARREMORE, ANDREW MILLS, HENRY KIDDLE, THOS. HARRISON and others, who gave the graduating class some good advice relative to their future life.

BALDWIN--PUNCHARD.--In Andover, on Tuesday, Feb. 22, at Christ Church, by Rev. Jamos Thomson, Mr. HALE E. BALDWIN, of Yonkers, to Miss SARAH ELIZABETH PUNGHARD, of Andover. BURROWS--LEGGETT.--On Monday, Feb, 21, by Rev. M. Frenshi JOHN BURROWS, of New-York, to ELIZA, second daughter of Mr. G. Leggett, of Stow? market, England.

Mr. CAMERON presented the memorial of a Committee of the Common Council and Franklin Institute of Philadelphia, and of the Pennsylvania Legislature, asking Congress to cooperate with the movement for a centennial celebration of the anniversary of American Independence, and to fix the place therefor. Referred.

The remarkable success which attended our negotiation of the Loans of the CENTRAL PACIFIC RAILROAD COMPANY and the WESTERN PACIFIC RAILROAD COMPANY, and the popularity and credit which these Loans have maintained in the markets, both in this country and Europe, have shown that the First Mortgage Bonds of wisely located and honorably managed Railroads are promptly recognized and readily taken as the most suitable, safe,

There was a stormy scene? the Corps Legislatiff to-day. M. OLLIVIER announced that the Government, in accordance with the liberal course it had market out, proposed to abandon wholly the system of placing in the field and supporting official candidates for the Chamber.

On Wednesday evening the City Mission held its monthly meeting in the Alexander Presbyterian Church, Seventh-avenue. A number of the missionaries related incidents of their observations and experiences in tenement houses, mission stations, , and showed the power of Christian sympathy in dealing with all sorts and conditions of men.

The Milwaukee brewers have made a reduction of $2 60 per barrel in the price of lager. Prince Edward County, in the Province of Ontario, has no debt, no toll-gates, and no whisky, but it has good roads and light taxes. Milwaukee is to have an Irish daily and weekly paper. The company has boon chartered.

Mr. BENNETT, representing the Buffalo District in Congress, has secured the reference to the Committee on Commerce of a bill to "provide for the better protection of the Northern and Northwestern frontier, and to facilitate commerce and diminish the expenses of exchanges between States."

The Supreme Court of Philadelphia, Chief Justice THOMPSON presiding, yesterday rendered a decision in favor of the proposed lease of the Atlantic and Great Western Railway to the Erie Company, and peremptorily dismissed the bill of exceptions that had been filed by the first mortgage bondholders and other opposing parties, the parties opposed to the lease being ordered to pay costs.

A rear tenement house, situated at No. 38 Bridge-street, was yesterday evening the scene of a tragedy of a startling and unusual character. On Wednesday allaboring man named JOHN MCCAIRNS, and his wife, moved into a room in that building. They were last seen in their usual health at 10 o'clock on Wednesday evening.

Those engaged in forming this Association held an adjourned meeting at Christ Chapol, in Chrystic-street near Broome, last evening. Mr. ALBERT WOODRUFF occupied the chair, and Mr. BARNSAD acted as Secretary. A form of constitution was submitted by Mr. BALDWIN on behalf of the Committee appointed for that purpose, whlch was read and adopted.

At noon yesterday the Special Committee of the Common Council appointed to tender a reception to Hon. WM. H. SEWARD on his approaching visit to this City, held a second meeting in the chamber of the Board of Aldermen. The meeting was presided over by Alderman MILLER.

A general meeting of Presbyterians was held yesterday afternoon, in Dr. ADAMS' Church, in Madison-sqnare,in accordance with an ancient custom of that denomination to engage on prayer for their colleges, and for the conversion of the youth educated therein. The Church was well tilled, and addresses were made by Drs. ADAMS, HASTINGS and PAXTON, and prayers were offered by Drs. HUTTON, MURRAY and JOHN HALL. Dr.

The Barkentine Ephraim Williams, of NowYork, Captain HUFF, bound from Mobile to Boston with cotton, put into Gardner's Bayfor a harbor during the gale of Friday of last week, having carried away truss band to foreyard. The Captain went to Orient on Saturday, and had new bands fitted, and arrived on board too late to do anything on that day.

The Business Committee reported the many appointments to the State Committee, charged with disseminating and rendering practicable the principles adopted by the Convention on Wednesday. It was resolved that the Convention express no opinion concerning the desirability of lay delegations.

Everybody recalls the fever for Central American and South American colonization which seized some of our people in 1865. It raged chiefly m the South, where, at the close of the war, some heartless or deluded ultra-Confederates persuaded many of their countrymen to quit their native shores forever, rather than to return to the "hated Union."

The installation of Rev. JOHN MURRAY FORBES. D. The proceedings were witnessed by a large number of clergymen, the Professors and students of the Seminary, and an immense gathering of the generall public.

A man named LEWIS ALDENBURTEL was committed to Ludlow-street Jail by Commissioner OSBORN, in July last, on a charge of passing counterfeit fractional currency notes. EDWARD and DANIEL AGNEW, two bigamists, have been arrested here and committed to prison to answer the charge of adultery. They have wives in Philadelphia, and some two months since married two young girls named DOUGHERTY and CHESTER.

Gold still goes down. Yesterday it touched 1161/3--the lowest figure yet reached, and a decline of 1 1/2 per cent. on the rate of Wednesday. The close connection between these reduced rates and the appreciation of our securities abroad, is the best evidence of the improvement that is going on in the nation's credit.

About a fortnight ago, E. C. HULL, a printer, residing in Hunter's Point, was arrested by the United States Marshal for forgery. Bail was at once procured, and the matter was kept a profound secret until yesterday, when the facts of the case became generally known. HULL was formerly engaged in the business of collecting soldiers' claims against the Government, and lived on Staten Island.

At a meeting of United States Assessors to consider the assessment of special taxes under the recent ruling of Commissioner DELANO, held yesterday at No. 108 Leonard-street, a question was introduced as to whether stone cutters need include in their manufactured sales the value of stones cut and dressed by them, but which they did not sell, and which they used in carrying out their building contracts under the builders' and contractors' license.

Another heavy rain storm occurred last night, making a total fall of the season of fifteen and a half inches. Abundant crops are almost certainly assured by the rains, and the people in the southern section of the State are jubilant over the improved prospects of the 'crops.

The steamer Emma No. 3, Captain JAMES H. MARATTA, left here for New-Orleans on the night of the 2d of February, with all the freight she could carry. The National Bank of New-Canaan was robbed last night by three New-York burglars, who entered the bank about midnight, gagged and bound the watchman, and went to work to drill late the safe. For a short time the glassy surface was surrendered to Mr. BRADY, the winner of the gold medal at the late competition, and to Mr. DOLLARD, Well known in the skating cirles of Brooklyn. Those gentlemen executed a number of intricate movements to the great satisfaction of the spectators.

The skating yesterday may be briefly described as being very bad. Indeed, except at the Rink in Third-avenue. there was none in this City, and even there the ice was so soft and so cut up that skating was performed under difficulties, and after a few turns most of those present seemed to have had enough of it. Yesterday not a flake of ice was to be seen on any of the open ponds.
Gov. CHURCH returned to his old home in Albion several days age in accordance with the purpose to do so which we announced some time since. The change has already been happy in its effect.

ADOLPH MARKETS, salesman for VOGEL BROTHERS, at No. 128 Church-street, was yesterday arraigned before Justice HOGAN, on a charge of larceny from his employers. Mr. LOUIS VOGEL testified that on Friday night he placed $305 in the safe, and carefully locked it. Yesterday morning he opened the safe, and saw the money there.

The "bull" movement of Friday was of brief duration, and yesterday morning, before the Board, the market broke, and prices came down with a rush almost as sudden as the advance had been on Friday morning. the "bears" were strengthened by the passage of the Funding bill in the United States Senate. The first recorded sale was at 112. The price was then run down at 1113/4, and subsequently advanced to 1123/8.

The Legislative Committee, of which Mr. L. D. KIERNAN is Chairman, held a final session at Castle Garden yesterday and took the testimony of some of the emigrants on Ward's Island, respecting the food furnished at the hospital. This evidence was simply cumulative, and tended to show that the food was insufficient in quantity and poor in quality.

Mr. BEARD is busy on a series of cartoons illustrating the legend of tile Indian Maiden, who was transformed into a white doc. The first picture only has been completed. If the remainder are as spirited and graceful as this, the series is likely to attract considerable attention. Mr. BEARD has also on the easel an unflaished sketch of" Death and Sorrow" striving to reach the Kingdom of Heaven.

In our telegraphic column, yesterday, we published a brief report of the forcible release of the prisoners confined in the jail at Charleston, West Va., by a bend of armed men who are styled "Kuklux." The Wheeling Intelligencer of Tuesday has a report of the affair, from which it appears that the organization is wide spread and the civil authorities powerless.

One has been in operation for some years in London, and others are being laid--some for passengers, others for freight. The "Beach Pneumatic Transit Tunnel" is, therefore, no experiment.

Contrasts of color will be avoided this season, and rich, almost imperceptible shadings of the same tint will be found on bonnets and robes. This will exercise one's taste exactly, for there is as much discord in the shades of a color as in two high tints. Blues especially kill each other, unless selected with the nicest taste.

The Young Men's Christian Association have done a very wise thing in establishing courses of weekly lectures in their ball in Twenty-third-street. It is especially useful that scientific instruction is here given both to the outside public and the young men of the Association.

Under the new city charter, which has already passed the House of Representatives, and will be pretty certain to pass the Senate and become a law, the limits of New-Orleans will be extended to the lower line of the City of Carrolton, including that portion of the Parish of Jefferson which was occupied by Jefferson City, Rickerville and Greenville.

The returns of the State census, recently made, show some interesting results. Although there are some reasons to feel doubt as to the perfect accuracy of these returns yet, in a general way, they are valuable.

The downward tendency of prices in many directions, and the expectation that they must full lower, have almost inevitably directed attention to the question of wages, The cost of labor must, it is said, be lessened, to balance the diminished returns which those who employ it are forced to accept.

By a royal decree published the past week a batch of fifteen new Senators has been patted up. The conservative branch of the Legislature has now nearly three hundred members. Except on extraordinary occasions, not more than sixty or seventy are in the habit of coming together.

TOBIAS BOUCK, of Schoharie, went into the City Bank today to deposit $1,200, left his money on the desk, and stepped in the back room to see the Cashier. When he returned the money was gone. The case was given to Detective BRADT. and in a few hours he recovered the money by arresting LEWIS H. THOMPSON and HENRY SNYDER, of Greenbush.

The Central Underground Railroad to Harlem has a good prospect of at least being soon commenced. A contract was signed last week on behalf of the English capitalists, with whom negotiations were carried on last year, to complote the road to the Harlem Railroad Depot, at Forty-second-street, within two years, and $10,000,000 security was given for its fulfillment.

MILLER had been stationed for about a year past at Austin, Texas, and was recently ordered to Detroit, and was on his way there with his family, when his death occurred.

Ex-Mayor WILLIAMSON H. HORN, whose death at the age of seventy-one years is announced this morning, and JAS. W. MCCLELLAND, whose remains reached here yesterday, were warm friends, their regards for each, other amounting almost to a brotherly affection. the lamented MCCLELLAND died far from home.

A large number of leading business men of Chicago have signed a call for a mass meeting to-night, for the purpose of memorializing Congress, and adopting such other means as may be deemed proper to secure an early reduction of taxes, both under the Internal Revenue laws and Tariff laws.

There has been an encouraging change in the ice question within five days. so far as the ice crop of the Hudson River is concerned. Full and authentic reports have been received from all points south of this city, on both sides of the river. At Coyemans, the Washington Company have twenty thousand tens housed.

The history of the Central Park is in various ways very noteworthy. The construction of the Park was the first attempt at landscape gardening on a great scale ever made on this continent, and what gave it still greater interest was that, although a NewYork work, it was made under the best conditions as regards the fitness of the men who wore to engage in it.

Gov. AUSTIN, of Minnesota, declined to sign the bill submitting the question of female suffrage to the people for the following reasons: Section 1 of article 7 of the State Constitution provides who shall be" voters" in this State; and section 1 of article 14 provides that no amendment prepared by the Legislature shall be adopted unless a majority of voters present and voting shall have ratified the same.

The ice blockade, which has so long and successfully impeded navigation, has at last been broken up as far as Poughkeepsie. The greatest barrier was from West Point to Pollipel's Island. At this place the immense masses of floating pieces from all the open upper Hudson had floated down, being driven together by the force of wind and current and wedged or dovetailed in a solid field.

The world and his wife and children are busily engaged in preparations for planting corn, the 17th of March being the day which, in this latitude, is considered the day for putting the seed in the ground. I do not believe that this day has been fixed out of compliment to St. Patrick, to whom it belongs in the calendar.

The radical papers of Paris are said to be most severe upon JULES FAVRE for having, in his last speech in the Corps Legislatif, promised his support to the Ministry. The king of Belgium is expected in Paris today.

GRANT, and subsequently by GRANT himself. The Sherman Funding bill, as it has passed the Senate, is intended to frustrate this wise propose.

MADRID, March 13.--The meeting between Prince HENRI DE BOURBON and the Duke DE MONTPENSIER took place on Saturday morning, seven miles from the walls of Madrid. The principals drew lots for the first shot, and Prince HENRI won. The adversaries exchanged their first fire at ten paces, without result. They then advanced on each other.

The state of the real estate market during the past week, as exhibited in the public sales at the Exchange, has not improved. A large proportion that usual of the sales announced were not actually consummated, and where they were peremptory by order of Court, the prices obtained were in general unsatisfactory.

The most extensive religious interest ever known in the history of Newburg, on the Hudson, has prevailed throughout the Methodist and Baptist Churches during the past Fall and Winter months. In both the Methodist Churches this feeling began to be manifested during the Fall, and may be said to have had its source in the remarkable fervor demonstrated at the sessions of the great Camp Meeting at Wesley's Grove last Summer.

The storm which has just visited this section commenced in rain and sleet on Saturday night, and in this form continued without interruption until soon after midnight, when it changed to snow, and by morning had covered the ground to the depth of about four inches.

NORTH PLATTE, Neb., March 12.--At a late hour last night a man named KIEF was knocked down and robbed of this watch and about a hundred dollars in currency. Mr. KIEF was so brutally beaten that his recovery is doubtful. The desperadoes are, without a doubt, the same party that robbed the jewelry store of McLUCAS DICK, not long since.

The Funding bill, as it passed the Senate, is not received with much favor in Wall-street, nor is it likely to be acceptable to the country at large, unless very materially changed in the House of Representatives.

Collector GRINNELL seems determined to make to the collection of customs at this Port as thorough as is possible with the ample machinery at his command, and at the same time afford to merchants and importers, who have good passing throught the custom-house, every facility consistent with his duty Government. .

OMAHA, Neb., March 12.--The Howie murder case is still pending. The jury cannot agree, and have been ordered to be locked up until 9 o'clock in the morning, at which time the Court will meet them. The jury were allowed there dinners and suppers. The women look pale and fatigued, this being the fourth night of their detention.

The London Times, in supporting the late decision of the Supreme Court of the United States,--that Congress had not the power to apply the provisions of this act to pre-existing debts,--suggests that individual foreign creditors of the respective States of the Union may now proceed in the United States Courts to enforce the collection of the difference between coin and paper on the payments of principal and interest accepted under protest.

BOSTON, March 13.--This evening a fire broke out in the building Nos. 41 and 43 Pearl-street, in the rooms occupied by WELD, BRYANT Co., dealers in shoe manufacturers' goods, and Messrs. HOWE WILLEY, dealers in morocco. Both of these firms had large stocks on hand, all of which was destroyed.

A meeting of the Executive Committee of Arrangements for a National Congress on the subject of Penitentiary and Reformatory Discipline was held yesterday at the Bible House in this City. It was decided to hold a National Congress, to consider these topics, in Cincinnati on the 20th of next September.

ANTONIO CATTUCEE, MARCO BALAFRE and PUBLO MARICI, natives of Italy and ignorant of English, were brought up before United States Commissioner NEWTON, yesterday, charged with manufacturing conterfelt coins on their premises at No. 43 York-street. The men were selzed by Col. WHITELY, Mr. APPLEGATE and several officers.

The whole evening was occupied in discussing the question whether the sitting members or the contestants from certain Assembly Districts were entitled to seats.

The Angle-American war for the control of Eric has now opened in earnest, and the contest promises to be protracted and vigorous. Yesterday an attempt was made to serve some papers issued at the instance of the American lawyer of the English stockholders on some of the Erie managers, but, in consequence of the vigilance of the sentinels of the Erie stronghold, resulted in failure.

RICHMOND, Va. March 14-The Legislature today passed the bill prescribing that all persons elected or appointed to office in the state shall take the Fourteenth Amendment oath. The law is to be in effect for one year form its passage.

Ensign CHARLES A. COPP, who was lost on the Oneida, was of the bravest and best of the gallant fellows who went down with their ship. From a newsboy he rose to the position of trust, which he held through his own endeavors. He was born in Troy, on July 25, 1847, and came from an old and respected New-Hampshire family.

It was announced several weeks ago that all correspondence and negotiations upon the Alabama claims had been suspended. WAVERLY, N. Y., March 14.--The Waverly National Bank, G. W. BUCK, President, was robbed early on Sunday morning. The burglars effected an entrance through a window. The frame of the new outer vault door was wedged off sufficiently to allow a large charge of powder to be poured in, which was ignited by a long fuse pushed through the opening.

WASHINGTON, March 14.--The bark Grapeshot, GEORGE LAW, claimant, vs. WOLLERSTEEN MASSETT, et al. Appeal from the Circuit Court for the District of Louisiana. The Grapeshot was seized under an Admiralty warrant and sold to pay advances for repairs in pursuance of a decree of the District Court belwo, made before the war.

Dispatches from Hong Kong, by way of London, state that the Captain of the Bombay had been suspended, not on account of the collision with the Oneida, but for neglecting to ascertain the extent of the injury done, and for taking no measures to save the drowning crew.

What is called a "mass meeting of working women" took place a few days ago in this City, and, on that occasion, various questions were discussed of interest to that large and increasing section of the female sex which is obliged to "work for a living."

HAVANA, March 14. -- Late advices from Nuevitas have been received. Gen. GOYENCHE had arrived at Cascorro and would soon march on the town of Guaimaro, Gen. PUELLO's forces occupy the towns of Sabanicu and San Miguel and were erecting fortifications. Cascorro was also being fortified.

A meeting of property holders on Twenty-sixth, Twenty-seventh, Twenty-eight and Thirtieth streets, between Sixth-avenue and the North River, was held last evening at Twenty-Sixth-Street, to take measures to prevent the laying of the stow Foundation Pavement in those thoroughfares.

"THE MARRIAGE OF FIGARO" AT THE ACADEMY, BEAUMARCHAIS was the original inspirer of MOZART's "Marriage of Figaro." The burlesque comedy of the former created one of the greatest sensations Paris had ever known. The triumph of the French satirist suggested, to MOZART that, with an Italian libretto, he could make a fine opera and a profounder impression.

The Inman steam-ship City of Washington, which left Liverpool March 3, and Qucenstown March 4, reached this port yesterday. The news thus received is later by three days than that at hand by the America.

The investigation in the case of Capt. JOHN ALEXANDER, who was alleged to have been poisoned, was concluded yesterday by Coroner FLYNN. The examination room was thronged by spectators and opposing counsel in the case. One of the jurors again delayed the proceedings by his tardiness in coming.

The Court room was densely packed, and considerable interest was manifested in the proceeding.

The Journal has a dispatch from New-Bedford stating that THEODORE L. PARKER, a grocer, aged twenty-one years, was shot and killed this evening by ELIZABETH B. An adjourned meeting of those interested in the Midland Railroad was held yesterday afternoon at the Produce Exchange, Mr. A. E. MASTERS in the chair. The New-Jersey Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church is now holding its thirty-fourth annual session at Long Branch, Bishop SIMPSON presiding. The session commenced on Wednesday, when Rev. J. D. KING was elected Secretary, and the opening business was transacted. Resolutions expressive of the sorrow occasioned by the death of Rev. Dr. McCLINTOCK and Bishop THOMSON were adopted.

There is no doubt that great improvements have been made since the system was first put in operation, but there is room for still further salutary changes.

A circular ordering the Brethren to convene at the ward school-houses for drill was privately circulated through Salt Lake on Friday. Drilling and arming continues throughout the Territory. Fifty Danites are said to have been enrolled since BRIGHAM YOUNG'S return.

The first anniversary of the settlement of Rev. G. D. MATHEWS, who was called from Scotland as pastor of the United Presbyterian Church in Jane-street, was celebrated yesterday at that church. In the forenoon Rev. Mr. MATHEWS preached from Acts xx., 24, on "The Gospel "Ministry, its Source, Message, and Mode of Performance."
In the Senate yesterday a resolution was passed that when the Legislature adjourn it adjourn to meet on the first Wednesday in July. No other business of importance was transacted.

The services at the Fourth Presbyterian Church in Thirty-fourth-street, west of Broadway. were well attend yesterday, large audiences having been drawn thither by the announcement that the preachers were to be Very Rev. Principal WILLIS, of Knox's College, Toronto, and Rev. Dr. BLAIKIE, one of the Scottish delegation to America.

The sixth anniversary of the German Young Men's Christian Association, of New-York; was celebrated last evening in the Houston-street Dutch Reformed Church. Prayer was offered by Rev. Pastor BUSCHE, imploring the Divine favor for continued prosperity to the glorious mission of tins union of Christian young men, and that their offerings might be rendered acceptable to their God.

Before Judge BENEDICT, at the United States Court, in Brooklyn, Saturday, appeared five injured seamen on a libel signed by three of their number, named JOHN LAWSON, JOHN T. ROMULUS and CHARLES OLSON, against SAMUEL P. ADAMS and others, owners of the ship Nellie Chapin.

Yesterday morning the little village of Hicksville, Long Island, was thrown into great excitement by the discovery of the body of a wealthy and respected farmer, named DAVID NOSTRAND, suspended from a beam in the hayloft, and now and then a drop of blood falling from it to the floor below.

The Nation informs the public that at the recent private meeting of "revenue reformers" in Washington, views were interchanged on the subject of tariff reform, the currency, and civil service reform; and it was resolved " to push these reforms in the Republican Party if possible, but out of it if necessary."

There was a quite a good attendance at the usual Sunday evening temperance meeting held at the Cooper Institute last night. Dr. A. S. BALL presided. Mr. MERRITT made a brief address on the different modes of putting down in temperance, and indorsing the anti-dram-shop party as the one most likely to succeed. All other plans had proved failures.

W. C. DUNHAM agent of the New-York and Virginia Steamship Line, who was one of the victims of the late disaster, died at noon today. Ex-State Treasurer JOHN S. CALVERT is believed to be in a dying condition.

A telegram per the Atlantic Cable from London, published in our second edition yesterday, announced that a rumor was in circulation to the effect that the American Consul at Jeddo, Japan, had been killed by the natives.

According to the latest estimates, the sugar crop this year will be fifteen per cent. less than than of last. Many plantations have finished grinding, and all will have concluded in about a fortnight.

There is as yet nothing new to report in relation to the Schuylkill suspension. The operators are no nearer a settlement, anal the men have no better prospect for a righting of their wrongs, if wrongs they have. The men in their present position get but little sympathy from any quarter but their own, and consumers in particular view them with especial distrust.

The heartiness and unanimity with which the Republican Press throughout the State indorses the ticket nominated by the party for the Court of Appeals may, it is hoped, be taken as an indication that an earnest and determined effort will be made to elect it.

JULES FERRY gave notice that on the following day he would put a question to the Chief Minister upon the subject of the alleged conspiracy, to which M. OLLIVIER replied: I have to inform you that I shall be here at the opening of the Chamber, but I am sorry to say I shall not answer.

Mr. CORNELL S. FRANKLIN tendered his resignation as Deputy Naval Officer on Saturday last, after having been connected with the Cnstom-house for nearly thirty years. He entered the Federal service on Oct. 1, 1841, as clerk to THOMAS LORD, Esq., then Naval Officer under President HARRISON.

About 2 o'clock yesterday morning GEORGE LIEVNEUR, who resides at No. 3 Varick-place, was on his way home and was passing the corner of Bleecker and Mott streets when he was suddenly attacked by a desperado known as WILLIAM DAVIDSON, who, striking him on the head with some missile that made two severe cuts. at the same moment seized his watch.

About 9 o'clock last might, a man made his appearance near the corner of Fourth and Green streets whose actions created some excitement. He started a minstrel show, and told the boys who had congregated around him that he would show them how JOHNNY ALLEN does "Josephus Orange Blossoms," and after singing awhile, he danced.

President GRANT attended the morning services of St. Paul's M. E. Church, at the corner of Jersey-street and Jefferson-avenue, Elizabeth, with the family of Mr. A. R. CORBIN, yesterday. The little church was crowded with spectators, and 500 or 600 persons waited outside to get a glimpse of the distinguished party as they came out. With the President were Mrs. GRANT.

Yesterday was an exceptional Sabbath, in the sense that it was not dabbled with human blood wantonly shed in those rum-hole riots which of late have been so alarmingly frequent. Beyond this, however, the day was not an improvement upon its immediate predecessors.

Nearly all the Kentucky distilleries stop Making whisky today. The Phlladelphia Telegraph reports that business in that city was never so flat as now. Thirty citizens of Arkansas have given Gov. CLAYTON a carriage. A young lady in Providence has recovered $300 damages for breach of promise of marriage.

This morning the trial of McFARLAND will enter upon its nineteenth day, and bids fair to occupy the attention of the Court for the remainder of the week. The District-Attorney proposes to consume all of to-day and part of tomorrow In examination of witnesses in rebuttal, but the cross-examination of these will doubtless be lengthy, so that this portion of the case may not be concluded before Wednesday morning or noon of that day.

Probably one strong reason that the sales of real estate have, during the last week, been even more extensive than usual, was the near approach to the 1st of May. But whatever may have been the cause, it is a fact that the property offered was of a superior quality, and the prices obtained better on the whole than for some weeks past.

The dramatic week does not promise to be very animated. To-night, however, the frequenters of Niblo's may witness a new play, entitled ' Mosquito," and written expressly for Miss LYDIA THOMPSON, who is to fill the leading part. Wednesday, a change of bill at the French Theater will introduce Mr. CHARLES FECHTER in "Don Caesar de Bazan."

The billiard tournament closed at a late hour last evening The event of the evening was a match for the championship, between NELMS and PLUNKETT, for a gold and ivory cue and a billiard table, 200 points.

The writer's remarks were directed chiefly to the services which are "performed"--for that seems the proper word-at Christ Church, corner of Thirty-fifth-street and Fifth-avenue.

The Canal Board held a meeting yesterday to hear discussions on the question of a reduction of canal tolls. Delegations were present from Now-York, Albany, Buffalo, Rochester and other places. Mr. HIRAM NILES, of Buffalo, spoke at some length in favor of the reduction of tolls on upward freight.

The passage of the Funding bill, and the concurrent resolution for the reduction of tolls, have inaugurated anew era in the canal policy of the State which is full of hope to the commercial interests of our own people as well as to the great West.

Tile drawing for the conscription has occasioned serious disturbances, despite the assurances of the Government organs to the contrary. At Sauz, a little village near Saragossa, a number of young men refused to draw, and made a demonstration against the conscription.

I was attracted the other day by the "Political Degeneracy" article of Putnam, and read it. Every newspaper correspondent--except myself--and every magazine writer who ventures on politics thinks it a part of his solemn duty--a mission--for want of any other--he was sent into the world to perform, to abuse public men and talk of the degeneracy of the times!

The Common Councils of Jersey City and Bergen held their final meetings Saturday night, and adjourned sine die, to make way for the Council of the consolidated city, which is to meet on Tuesday next. All the members of the Jersey City Council, with two exceptions, were present, but there were few spectators to watch the closing scenes of the City Legislature.

The name of ZERAH COLBURN is known to the engineers of all countries where professional literature exists, and his writings are perhaps more various in scope and more vigorous in practical treatment than those of any other member of his profession. In his death engineering sustains an irreparable loss.

A meeting in behalf of the Evangelical Alliance was held last evening at the Baptist Church, corner of Madison-avenue and Thirtyfirst-street, the pastor, Dr. ELDER, in the chair. The Secretary, Dr. ELDRIDGE, informed the meeting that the measures which were adopted with reference to the great Conference to be held in September next gave promise of being a grand success.

Gen. PARKER, Commissioner of Indian Affairs, estimates the Indian warriors in the neighborhood of Fort Sully at about 8,000. They are well armed and mounted. About 6,000 of these are Sioux, and the remainder is made up of scattering tribes.

The forty-sixth anniversary of the NewYork Bible Society was celebrated last evening at the South Reformed Church at the corner of Twenty-first-street and Fifth-avenue. The annual report was read by D. S. EVERSON, Esq., the Corresponding Secretary, from which it appeared that the agents of the Society had visited 48,810 families during the year.

The reported conspiracy to kill the Emperor and blow up the Police head-quarters in Paris is pronounced a fabrication in the Paris dispatch of this morning. The amnesty which was to have been proclaimed on the 12th inst., will not be issued.

The annual sermon of the Protestant Episcopal Church Missionary Society for Seamen in the City and Port of New-York, was preached, yesterday evening, by Rev. Dr. SCHENCK, in the Church of St. Aun's, on the Heights, Brooklyn.

At the Exchange yesterday there were no sales, and a general air of dullness pervaded the market. Much of this probably may be attributed to the fact that it was moving-day, and a number of those usually at the rooms were absent in other parts of the City. Today several sales are to take place.

The May term of the Court of General Sessions commenced yesterday, Judge BEDFORD presiding. RICHARD BURNS pleaded guilty to having stolen $91 worth of clothing from JOHN BYRNE, of No. 684 Sixth-avenue. It appeared that he decamped with the property after one day's residence with the complainant as a boarder.

The liquor-dealers are extremely hard to please, for not satisfied with the almost unconditional surrender of the Excise Commissioners to their interests, they are protesting against the schedule of license fees which has been decided upon. To do this effectively a meeting was held of the Liquor-dealers' Association and a Committee was appointed to wait upon the Commissioners and cuter the protest.

As an indication of the greatly increased emigration that will find its way to the United States from ports in the Baltic during the current year, we learn on authority that arrangements were completed some time since to convey, during the Summer and Fall months, about 50,000 Scandinavians, Swedes, Norwegians and Danes, to this port.

A large meeting of some of the Ieading citizens of the City was held at Mr. STEWART'S store, yesterday afternoon, to take some action as to the best means for preventing the Arcade Railroad bill from becoming a law. All the gentlemen present own more or less property on Broadway, and the aggregate value of the property represented was estimated at $300,000,000.

In the TIMES of yesterday was printed the report of the horrible death of DAVID NOBTRAND, of Jericho. There were very few new facts elicited yesterday, going to prove other than that he committed suicide while laboring under temporary derangement. He went to New-York on Monday last, since which time his conduct has been strange.

They were removed to the Station-house, when PHILLIPS appeared to be insensible, and he died before a surgeon arrived.

The McFarland trial entered upon its fifth week and nineteenth day yesterday. The Courtroom was crowded to its utmost capacity, and had it not been for a pardonable ruse on the part of the officers, who, after an adjournment of the Oyer and Terminer.

A Paris dispatch says another arrest of an armed man was made on Sunday at the racecourse where the Emperor was expected. He proved to be an insane Englishman, and had no connection with the conspiracy, although it was said that at his residence a quantity of bombs were discovered. The ramifications of the Plot are said to be wider than at first supposed, and arrests continue to be made in all directions.

It was generally supposed that some important changes would have been made in the Mayor's office yesterday, and that at least one official would have been removed; but it appears that all misunderstandings have been explained and that the clerical force of the office will remain as at present.

The tide of May-movers from Brooklyn to New-York is larger than the tide the other way, for the first time in several years. There have crossed the Hamilton Ferry to Brooklyn since April, 222 loads, sixty-three of which went over yesterday. There has been about the same number the other way. At the South Ferry there was little travel of this kind, not more than tive carts passing over to Brooklyn.

The joint resolution introduced in Congross yesterday by Mr. SCHENCK, to make the 30th of May a national holiday, as a memorial of our dead soldiers, and of the national victory over the rebellion, will revive the discussion which was had a year or two ago as to the policy of thus perpetuating the memories of the war.

The trial in the case of JOHN J. NIXON, charged with the Bloomingdale murder, was continued yesterday, at Paterson, before Judges BEDLE, SANFORD, TERHUNE and DAGGERS. HENRY VAN NESS and TUNIS H. FREELAND testified to the appearance of the bloody clothes of NIXON, and of the body of SISCO when found.

A man named FRIEDMAN was examined in the United States Commissioner's Office, yesterday, concerning the charge made against IGNATZ ILLFOWSKY, or SLOWSKY, of having tampered with Government witnesses. His testimony was to the effect that he was subpoenaed as a witness for the Government in the Barker distillery case.

An unusually interesting meeting of ladies of the County Suffrage Association was held yesterday afternoon at an elegant private residence in Thirty-fourth-street. The first hour was spent in parliamentary drilling, as is the custom at those gatherings.

The Democratic Union City and County Convention met at Masonic Hall last evening. Mr. ROSWELL D. HATCH called the meeting to order, and Mr. SMITH ELY was subsequently chosen Chairman, Messrs. JOHN HALLORAN and S. HEYMAN being selected as Secretaries.

The first meeting of the Common Council of the consolidated City of Jersey City was held last evening. A large audience was present. Aldermen McNULTY, of Hudson City, was unanimously elected President, and JOHN E. SCOTT was elected City Clerk.

A special meeting was held by the Chamber of Commerce yesterday afternoon, Mr. GEO. OPDYKE presiding, in order to take action with regard to the recent calamity at Richmond, Va. On calling the meeting to order, the Chairman spoke of the affliction caused to the community of Richmond by the accident, and of the measurea of relief that ought to be taken.

Gov. ENGLISH'S inaugural address is full of political interest, as indicating the temper of the Democracy, and as foreshadowing the future policy which it is preparing to adopt. He declares the Fifteenth Amendment to be invalid as a part of the Constitution of the United States-first, by reason of irregularity in the methods of its adoption, and second, on account of its conflict with the organic law of Connecticut.

As some of the men employed in the car and repair shops of the Harlem Railroad Company at Central Morriesania were proceeding to their work early yesterday morning, they found the body of an unknown man suspended to a tree in the woods near by, The deceased appared to be a German about twenty-eight years old, and had evidently repaired to the spot fully prepared to carry out his design of self-destruction.

JOHM DEAL was hanged in the Prison Yard about 11/2 today in the presence of about two hundred persons. He was calm and made-a-few incoherent remarks on the scaffold, admitting his guilt and hoping for mercy in the future world. His struggles were not violent, and on being cut down the examination by the physician showed that his neck was not dislocated.

Notional assent is the belief of propositions which express abstractions.

The Coroner's Jury this afternoon rendered a verdict that the collission near Eureka last Thursday was all caused by the disobedience of orders and culpable negligence of WM. ODOR, conductor, and JOSEPH TRACY, engineer of tho extra freight train, in running said train at least fifteen minutes behind the time given them through orders of the train dispatchces.

In response to a call made by Senors MANUEL QUESADA and THOMAS JORDAN, a large andience assembled at Irving Hall last evening, to hear Gen. JORDAN and others make addresses in regard to the Cuban cause. The hall was a little more than half filled, and would probably have been crowded but for the shortness of the notice that the meeting would be held.

GEO. BENNETT was arraigned before JUS- tree HOGAN yesterday, at the Tombs, on a charge of keeping a disorderly house at No. 33 Chatham- street, and with him were arrested eight depraved women, who were found in the house when the Police made a descent on Sunday night on the occurrence of a disturbance among the inmates. BENNETT was remanded for trial, and the women were sent to be Island for six months each.

We had delayed this in order that the involuntary coincidence should not have the appearance of an electoral intrigue, but the revolutionists have not been stopped in their career by the legal amnesty which we granted.

An unsuccessful attempt was made this morning to introduce colored children into two of the public schools. A committee of eight, with three boys, (colored,) made the demand, which was refused upon the ground that instructions for the admission of colored children had not been given by the Superintendent.

The Democrats of one county in Kentucky have suggested Senator McCREERY for Governor. A Western paper complaius that the only success of an oculist recently in its locality was in enabling the flats who consulted him to cut their eye teeth.

It is estimated that the Fifteenth Amendment has put the ballot into the hands of at least 800,000 blacks in all the States, of whom about 700,000 reside at the South. The popular majority for Gen. GRANT in 1868 was nearly 310,000, or considerably less than onehalf the new negro vote.

The Board met in tHeir chamber, number fifteen City Hall, pursuant to adjournment. Present-Thomas Coman, Esq., President, in the Chair. A quorum failing to answer to their names on the call of the roll, the President declared that the Board stood adjourned without day.

At a mooting of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen, held yesterday, a commnication was received from the Mayor vetoing the appointment of R. R. TOOMBS as custodian of the registry of house and lot numbers in the city, on the ground that the salary of TOOMBS was not designated. Ordered on file.

Further particulars of the La Crosse disaster, recerved by the train today, state that four human lives were probably lost. They were a Miss MARY ULRICH, of La Crosse; the colored barber of the boat, and an old gentleman from Kentucky on a pleasure excursion, all supposed to have been burned to death on the boat and an elderly lady.

LAND GRANTS TO RAILWAYS. Mr. SPENCER Called up the bill granting public lands in the State of Alabama to the Decatur and Aberdeen Railroad. Passed. Mr. RUMSAY called up the bill granting lands to aid in the construction of a railroad from the western boundary of Minnesota, at the junction of Sioux Wood River with the Red River of the north to the Winnepeg District of British America.

The officers of the Kansas Pacific Railroad here confirm the report from Omaha yesterday of the Indian raid on their road. The attach was made on working men, between Kit Carson and Willow Springs, a distance of forty miles. Ten men, belonging to grading parties, were killed.

The investigation into the charges brought against Mr. John R. HENNESSEY, a School Trustee in the Seventeenth Ward, by Inspector ANDREW MILLS, for having, as is alleged, received a present of $100 for securing a position as teacher in the Fourteenth-street school for MISS MARY E. CANNON, was continued, yesterday, before Commissioners GROSS, LEWIS and SANDS, of the Board of Education.

It will be remembered by the readers of the TIMES that during the pendency of an action about a year ago, in which FRANK LESLIE sought to obtain a divorce from his wife, SARAG ANN LESLIE, an order was made in the Court of Common Pleas directing the payment of $50 a month ahmony to defendant, and a counsel fee of $500.

Let no man be deterred from voting today by any foregone conclusion touching the result of the contest. As regards the nominations for Aldermen, the Republican ticket contains such names as would do honor to any municipality in the world, and their superiority to the Democratic candidates is not questioned by any candid man on either side in politics.

A committee of twenty, appointed by the Council held in Albany in April, to perfect an organization for the State, have been in session in this City during several days past. As the result of their deliberations, it was determined that the ''New-York State Council of Political Reform" shall consist of 130 members, of whom at least one shall reside in each county.

There seems to be a very lively canvass going on between two opposing parties for the election of the Board of Directors of the Mercantile Library Association, which takes place today. One ticket, claiming to be "regular," represents the party which now has the management of the Library, and the other is put for the by the members styling themselves the reform party.

The Tax bill is a measure demanding careful consideration-but a disposition is being shown to hurry everything through the House as fast as possible, by way of proving to the nation that Representatives really can do business when they are in the humor. The proposed compromise in reference to the income tax will certainly not be acceptable to the people.

The operations of this new department of the Customs progress as favorably as Collector GRINNELL expected when he organized it. Under the management of Mr. TUNIS, it has met every requirement, and the report for the first fortnight of its organization showed an aggregate of $700 in duties collected, which may be considered a clear gain to the Government.
The steam ship Rapidan, from Havana May H. reached this port yesterday. By the courtesy of Purser OSCAR CROCHERON, our Havana correspondence, united below, was promptly received.

The result of the international yacht race which occurred on Saturday, forms a theme of newspaper comment and general conversation. It is reported that on the return of the tug Gem to Cowes, parties from on board industriously circulated the falsehood that the Sappho unfairly shot a milo and a half ahead at or before the signal to start.

The recent strikes at Creusot furnish a new illustration of the mischief effected by such men as ROCHEFORT. It was but a short time before the strike that comments were made in many European journals upon the exceptionably comfortable position of these workmen of M. SCHEIDER'S.

The Temperance General Committee, President JAMES BOYLE, met last night at their head-quarter, Masonic Hall, East Thirteenth-street. Considerable feeling was manifested in regard to the action of the Committee on Saturday night last, which, it was alleged, was not in accordance with the wishes of the majority at that meeting.

The official news from Captain-General DE RODAS in regard to affairs in Cuba, gives universal satisfaction n Madrid. Quite a debate took place in the Cortes on Saturday, between a Republican Deputy and Minister MORET, in which the former asserted that the war in Cuba still existed, while the latter denied the fact.

Voyagers up to Hudson this Summer will observe just after entering the Highlands, and rounding the rock point called St. Anthony's Nose, the tall chimney, the buildings and do?? of the extensive works now being rapidly erected on one of the low islands which at this point line the right bank of the river.

The inquest upon the bodies of BERNARD O'CONNEL and PETER MCGOVERN, who were killed on Saturday at the Magnolia-street crossing of the New-Jersey Central Railroad, in Elizabeth, was commenced before Coroner BRAINE yesterday afternoon.

The German merchants, bankers and brokers of this City, who resolved some time ago to establish a bank of discount in this City, held a meeting at the merchants' Exchange and News-rooms, Nos. 50 and 52 Pine-street, yesterday afternoon, Mr. JOSEPH SELIGMANN presiding, and Mr. FREDERICK KUHNE acting as Secretary.

By direction of the Secretary of War, Capt. and Brevet Lieut. Peter C. Harris, of the Corps of Engineers, is assigned to temporary duty under the direction of and will report by letter for instructions to the Secretary of the interior, for the purpose of examining and reporting upon twenty miles of the Little Rock and Fort Smith Railroad now ready for inspection.

A short season of Italian opera was begun last night at the Academy of Music, under circumstances uncommonly and, considering the season, surprisingly propitious. "It Prevatore" was the work selected for the opening, and the result showed the choice to be a wise one. Threadbare as the opera is, it has a tenacious hold on popular affection, and a house most uncomfortably full rewarded its presentation on this occasion.

Gen. J. EGBRERT FARNUM, who died yesterday morning at his residence in this City, was born in 1824 in New-Jersey, but was brought up in Pennsylvania. Displaying early in life an adventurous disposition and a love for a military career, when the Mexican war broke out he joined the First Regiment of Pennsylvania Volunteers, with which he served as Sergeant-Major until the close of the war.
