The sash and blind factory of the Messrs. McBLAU was burned on Saturday night, together with a large quantity of lumber; loss, $10,000; insurance, $4,000 ....TWO more companies of troops left this morning en route for Red River....The gun-boat Rescue is to be sent to St. Mary's River immediately, as a precaution against possible Fenian attacks.

Fashion not having yet sent forth its mandate that the proper time has come for people to enjoy the cool breezes of Long Branch, the place may now be seen to great perfection. You may stand on the beach at the Continental Hotel, and look down the long stretch of sand as far as the Stetson House, and see not a living creature.

DETROIT, H. CHAMBERS, aged sixty, shot himself through the head yesterday afternoon about 5 o'clock. He died last night. He is believed to have been temporarily insane. FRANCIS WAGNER shot himself dead at Bay City on Saturday at 11/2 o'clock. He was to have been married at 2 o'clock the same day. No cause is assigned for the act.

The trustees of this institution have secured the large building at the south-west corner of Second-avenue and St. Mark's-place, and ina few weeks will open it for the reception of patients. It will be the first hospital of the kind established in this country, the one for the paralyzed and epileptic on Blackwell's Island being no exception to this statement, as its range is limited.

Thirty-six policemen were arraigned before Commission BOSWORTH, yesterday, for the various offenses known in Police circles as proper conduct. A most singular case was that of Patrolman WM. A. MARTINEAU, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, who was charged by Rounds-man GROO with being off post three hours, but who produced a sergeant, six patrolmen and three citizens who had seen him during the time properly patrolling his post.

The steam-ships Idaho, from Liverpool May 4 and Queenstown May 5, and City of London, from Liverpool May 5 and Queenstown May 6, reached this port yesterday. The advices thus received are later by three days than were those at hand by the Bremen steam-ship on Friday.

Among the last words of great mon which form so interesting a part of the curiosities of biography, we question if anything more characteristic can be found than the remark made by the colored porter of the freighttrain on the Missouri Pacific Railroad, just before it dashed, the other day, into the passonger-cars, near Eureka.

The May term of the Court of Chancery commenced today, the fifty cases on the list. The most important case is that of MARTHA B. STEVENS and others vs. WM. B. SHIPPEN and others. This is a suit for the construction of the will of the late EDWIN A. STEVENS, of Hoboken- to have the Court determine whether certain charitable bequests, and the gift of the Stovens Battery to the State of New-Jersey, are valid.

The Board met in their Chamber, number fifteen City Hall, pursuant to a call signed by a majority of members. Present--Thomas Coman, Esq., President, in the chair, and the following members: Aldermen miller, Murray. Welch, Seger, McKiever, Cregior, Croker, Jackson, Cunningham,. Long--11.

One of the Piquet chiefs, the notorious SIFFRA, who was one of SALNAVE'S leaders, has escaped from Jeremic, and has appeared on the plains of Aux Cayes with a band of followers. They have burned and pillaged the village of Porta Parent, killing men, women and children, and committing most horrible atrocities.

The entire business part of Henderson, N. C., was destroyed by fire this morning. The fire was first discovered issuing from a store on Main-street belonging to Dr. DEDRIAM. It spread very rapidly, and soon consumed every building on both sides of the street for a distance of 200 yards. Every business house in the town was destroyed.

The fifty-fourth anniversary of the Sunday-School Missionary Union was held last evening at the Collegiate Reformed Dutch church, corner of Fifth-avenue and Twenty-ninth-Street, before a very large audience. Mr. J. W. C. LEVEREDGE Presided. The Secretary, Mr. P.H. Verson, read the annual report.

The eleventh commencement of the Law School of Columbia College will take place this evening. The degree of Bachelor of Laws will be conferred on members of the graduating class, and the annual prizes will be awarded. Addresses will be delivered by Prof. THEODORE W. DWIGHT, ADOLH L. SANGER and ORRIN SKINNER, Esq.

A case involving the attorney's right to his fees for professional services was decided in the Hudson County Supreme Court, Judge BEDLE presiding, yesterday. The action was brought by S. B. RANSOM, a lawyer of Jersey City, against ELISH A RUCKMAN, a wealthy resident of Bergen County, for $5,000 and half the cost of an arbitration to which the dispute had been submitted.

The returns from yesterday's election indicate beyond all question that the Democratic Judicial ticket has been elected by a large majority. An examination of the returns shows a large falling off in the Republican vote, and an average poll by the Demcrats. The result is, of course, not unexpected, although it is one which is much to be regretted.

The St. Joseph (Mo.) Herald records the death in that City of pneumonia, on the evening of the 9th inst., of Gen. ROBERT WILSON, who was born in Virginia in 1803. His mother was a relative of the late Hon. WILLIAM L. YANCEY, of Alabama. At an early age he removed to Franklin, Mo., and subsequently to Fayette, in the same State, and of that town he was the first Postmaster.

A few days since the President of the Cortes. M. ZORILLA, had a conference with M. RUANO, a Republican, and Secretary of the Chamber, in order to persuade him to abandon the idea of demanding an explanation of the Government on the subject of its intention of continuing the stutu quo. M. ZORILLA told the Republica Deputy that he would not repent of adjourning for a short time his interpellation.

The call issued by the Republican State Executive Committee of Delaware, for State Convention in Dover, on Thursday, June 9, to nominate candidates for Governor and Congressman, declares that the citizens of Delaware now have an opportunity for a change of administration, and appeals to them not to waste it.

Mexican advices to May 10 have been received. GARCIA CADENA, after again organizing a numerous band, attacked the town of Tuchipila and was repulsed. The Cuernavaca insurgents have been defeated, and afterward moved into the State of Puebla.

The anniversary meeting of the Mission Schools of the Presbyterian Church, Nincteenthstreet and Fifth-avenue, was briefly reported in our columns on Monday, and merits more lengthened notice from the success with which it was attended as well as from the importance of the Sabath school work carried on by Dr. HALL'S congregation.

For some time past special endeavors have been made, on the part of Customs officials, to discover the manner in which diamonds and other precious stones, on which heavy import duties were imposed, were smuggled into this port. That such smuggling was carried on to a formidable extent has long been suspected, but it was conducted so secretly and systematically that it was found almost impossible to discover the persons who were engaged in it.

A suit for a divorce is before the Massachusetts Supreme Court, brought by Mrs. LEWIS against her husband, Dr. LEWIS, on the allegation of adultery. The parties are the parents of CORINNA LEWIS, who was abducted some months ago by her father, and subsequently returned to her mother by order of the New-York Court...

The members of the Mercantile Library Association had an unusually warm contest yesterday over the election of directors for tile ensuing year. As the public has already been advised, there were two rival tickets in the field, each supported by an earnest and determined Party.

The libel suit against RICHARDSON BROTHERS, proprietors of the Davenport Democrat, brought by THOMAS FLUKE, Ex-Treasurer of Scott County, Iowa, is now on trial. FLUKE claims $15,000 damages. . . . The trial of PAULINE MARKHAM, LYDIA THOMPSON, ALEXANDER HENDERSON and ARCHIBALD GORDON for an assault upon Mr. STORY, editor of the Chicago Timer, took place today in the Recorder's Court.

STEWART, Esq., projected the scheme of raising a fund for the benefit of Mr. STANTON'S family. Mr. STEWART introduced the subject before the Club, and gave impetus to the plan by a subscription of $5,000.

ITALIAN OPERA. The second representation of the present series of Italian opera performances was given as the Academy of Music last evening. The opera of "Martha" was sung, with Signor BRIGNOLI as Lioncllo, Signor SUSINI as Plunketl, Miss McCULLOCH as Lady Henrlella, and Miss CLARA PERL as Nancy.

Those of our citizens who had occasion to travel about the City yesterday, and observed the quiet that prevailed in the various wards and election districts, the lack of all excitement or apparent interest in the election, and the absence of the crowds that usually through about the polling-places on election day, will be astonished at the heavy vote that is returned as having been cast, and will wonder where the votes came from.

' The Governor has vetoed the following bills: " To incorporate the New-York Annuity Company." The Governor objects that this bill contemplates allowing a company to begin business on an insufficient amount of capital, " Amending the act to simplify proceedings in the State Courts."

The Raleigh (N. C.) Standard asserts that during the deliberations of the Republican State Convention, which was held in that city last week, and remained in session two days, the greatest harmony prevailed. Hon. SAMUEL F. PHILLIPS was unanimously nominated for Attorney-General, Hon. LOUIS P. OLDS, the present incumbent, having declined a renomination.

NATHANIEL GALE, for many years a clerk in the Naval-office Department of the Boston Custom-house, Is charged with defrauding the. Government to the extent of $6,000 gold, in the collection of invoice duties. A merchant's clerk is charged as an accomplice. Both have been arrested and held for trial on Thursday.

Mr. CAMERON, in presenting a memorial for a general abolition of taxation on productions, said he thought the first duty of Congress were at par, he could see no reason why the working masses should be taxed upon their labor. He would favor, to a great extent, the substitution of external for internal taxes, and above all, the abolition of the tax on incomes.

The Common Conncil passed an order to-nignt submitting the question of loaning the credit of the city to the amount of $15,000 per mile to the Winterport Railroad to a vote of the citizens. The Board of Aldermen refused the order, and indefinitely postponed the matter.

A dispatch received by Gen. POPE from Gen. WOODS, commanding fort Wallace, Kansas, says he Indians attacked a water tank on the Kansas Pacific Railway, five miles cast of Kit Carson, Sunday morning, and were still in the vicinity Monday morning. A company of the Seventh Cavalry had been sent after them.

The perpetrators of the fraud, who are from New-York, have been arrested and a portion of the money recovered .... The billiard tournament was concluded yesterday. A large sale of lots takes place at New-Brighton, Staten Island, to-morrow, which deserves attention from those who would like to settle in this growing and beautiful, island in a convenient locality and at small cost. The property, which belongs to the estate of J. S. WESTERVELT, Esq., deceased, is within two minutes' walk of the steam-boat landing, and has all the advantages of healthfulness, fine view, convenience of access, and flagged and lighted walks.

For any approach to relief, in the shape of reduced taxation, we are disposed to be duly grateful. So far as the session of Congress has yet gone, the odds have seemed nearly all against the people. Trifling matters have been discussed with great prolixity, and measures not called for have been allowed to absorb the time which properly belonged to important public interests.

LUCIEN V. KNOWLES was arraigned before Justice HOGAN, yesterday, at the Tombs, on a charge of having used false pretences in obtaining a bill of goods to the value of $154 on a draft purporting to have been drawn for $158 40 by JOHN R. FARWELL CO., of Chicago, to the order of BENJAMIN KNOWER, and duly certified by the Metropolitan National Bank.

ESPARTERO has addressed a letter to Gen. PRIM declining to be a candidate for the Spanish throne on account of his advanced age. The settlement of the monarchy question is urged by the Press, and anxiety for the termination of the provisional status increases.

We trust the authorities will condescend to give us public baths. The fact that "cleanliness" is so near to " godliness may make the experiment distasteful in some quarters, but there is no fear that any amount of water, taken externally, will seduce the honest Democratic masses from their fidelity to JEFFERSON'S principles and JACKSON'S practice, or that the "great unwashed" will vote any the less often for being Republicanized in looks.

From the Richmond Whig. We do not suppose that such a contrast was ever exhibited between two rival parties in this country as was shown in the contest for power last year between the Conservatives and Radicals of this State. In numbers, they were not very far apart. In sentiment, in character and intelligence they were as distant as the antipodes.

When the Canadian Government, after concluding a very advantageous bargain with the Hudson Bay Company for the transfer of its jurisdiction over the Red River country, dispatched thither a Governor and suite to rule over the newly-acquired territory and its people, there proceeded from our own people a very general expression of opinion that the proceeding was unnecessarily arbitrary.

The chances of our enjoying swift means of transit up and down Manhattan Island at an early day look decidedly slender at present, although the need for such accommodation is constantly growing more pressing. The defeat of the Arcade project, and the unlucky accident on Monday to the West Side Elevated Railroad, coming, as it were, together, have had an effect on the prospects of rapid City locomotion which is the reverse of encouraging.

The delay in the departmental orgauization of the Board of Health of this City gives rise to grave fears for the sanitary welfare of the people. Standing as it does upon the threshold of the Summer season, and confronted by two epidemics-small-pox and relapsing fever-and innumerable nuisances detrimental to the public health, it seems a matter of the first necessity that this Board should immediately secure a most effective organization.

It is a sign of the moderate temper of our Republican Representatives in Congress that they declined to carry out the suggestion of Senator MORTON, to settle the policy and tactics of the approaching elections in caucus. This is no fitting time for taking so important a step.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The writer of this bought a house, for which he paid, say $10,O00,and had the deed made to his wife, for her benefit, in case he should die first. A will was made bequeathing the property to himself, for his benefit, should he be the survivor. The wife died, and Government demands of the husband $600, being six per cent. on $10.000. as succession tax.

ESPARTERO has written a letter to Marshal PRIM declining the candidacy for the Crown on account of his great age. The Cortes has passed the bill authorizing civil marriage by a vote of 142 yeas to 34 nays. The Press continues to urge a settlement of the question of the throne, and the anxiety in political circles for the termination of the provisional status daily increases.

Gen. JORDAN has issued an appeal to the ladies of New-York, in which he says that the women and children of Cuba are almost destitute of clothing. This extreme destitution, he says, has come upon them because their families, for the most part, had to leave, suddenly, their homes in the towns and cities, with little means of transportation.

At 12 1\2 o'clock this morning a fire broke out in the basement of the four-story brick building No. 273 Cherry-street, occupied by VAN TUYL Co. as a charcoal-crushing mill for the manufacture of foundry mold facings. The flames originated in some unknown manner near the furnace, probably from a spark shouldering among some waste charcoal.

A terrible accident occurred yesterday forenoon on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, near Mead's Basin. A construction train was passing over the long trestle-work over the Pequannock River, when the timbers gave away, precipitating the train into the river below.

The room is on the second floor, and larger than the one at present occupied, while the location is equally desirable.

Complaints respecting the treatment of the public by gas companies are continuous, both on the ground of extortion and the inferior quality of the article they supply. It will be some consolation to the grumblers to know that there actually seems a chance that we may by and by get gas, like petroleum, "out of the bowels of the harmless earth."

The game was very spirited, and the fine play of bothsclubs elicited much applause from the spectators. The Athletics went to the bat, scoring six runs.

The First six months of the existence of the Church Music Association were brought to a brilliant close by the concert of last evening. Steinway Hall was crowded on that occasion. by and extremely fashionable audience, and much gratification was expressed at the excellence of the performance.

Mr. ARCHIBALD, of Nova Scotia, the newly-appointed Governor of Manitoba, is represented to be a gentleman of high character, and excellent executive ability. A party of white men while On a pleasure trip to the Falls of the Yellowstone, had their stock stolen one night by a band of Indians, known as "Sheep Takers." They pursued the Indians at daybreak. The latter hastily constructed a raft and attempted to cross the Yellowstono Rivcr. About midway across, the current took the raft down the stream, and its eighteen occupants were swept over the Falls to instant death.

The Trustees of the Midnight Mission desire, once more to call attention to the fact that they are making an effort to create a "building fund" of $40,000, free of collectors' fees or personal solicitations, by asking for 1,000 voluntary, subscriptions, of $40 each. A fire this morning, caused by gas explosion in the grocery-store of P.P.PEARSON, destroyed the stock and badly injured the building. Mr. PEARSON was in the act of lighting a gas burner when the explosion took place. He was severely burned.

Mr. H. B. CROSSETT, owner of the little excursion steamer Wyoming, made a trip to the new pleasure grounds of Eagleswood, yesterday, with a company of invited guests and representatives of the Press. The day was perfect, the arrangements for the enjoyment of the company all that could be desired, and the unanimous decision was that a more delightful trip could hardly be made.

Mr. THURLOW WEED has a paner on "Early Incidents of the Rebellion" in the June Galaxy that will be read with deep attention, and mill impart some little knowledge in no obtrusive way of what Mr. WEED did for the country at a critical period, such as should inspire lasting respect and gratitude. We hope on Sunday to print extracts from this valuable contribution, and, meanwhile, recommend it to general nerusal.

It is only natural that the World should look at the result of the State and City election through its own spectacles. It sees things through the medium of colored glass. It finds in the vote a perfect confirmation of the policy which led it long ago to repudiate PENDLETON as a financier, and to discard FRANK BLAIR as a candidate for the VicePresidency.

In the Hudson County Court of Quarter Sessions, yesterday, the trial of CHAS. SCHULTZ for attempting to kill his wife by cutting her throat last March, in Hudson City, was continued. The prisoner is about seventy years old, and does not seem to comprehend his undesirable position.

The House of Lords tonight discussed the bill legalizing marriage with a deceased wife's sister, which came up for its second reading. Lord HOUGIITON advocated the abolition of the restriction. He cited Talmudic authority to prove that such marriage had the sanction of the remotest antiquity.

Mr. BRINTANO has covered the counters of his new store, No. 33 Union-square, with all the latest foreign publications. The funeral of Gen. J. EGBERT FARNUM took place yesterday. The services at his late residence in Stuyvesant-street, near Second-avenue, were very impressive. The remains respond in a beautiful coffin with silver mountings and plate, on which was inscribed the words: "JOSEPH E. FARNUM, died May 11, in the forty-seventh year of his age."

The trial of THOMAS HALLORAN for the murder of his wife was continued in the Morris County Court of Oyer and Terminer, yesterday. LAWRENCE EAGAN, brother of the deceased murdered woman, testified that after the murder he was at HALLORAN'S house; saw the prisoner there; he said he had "pulled his wife upstairs, and she was a heavy load."

The Forty-first Congress seems determined to acquire the proud distinction of having distanced all its predecessors in performing the minimum of work with the maximum of talk. The extract from a Red River letter, published in our Washington dispatches, yesterday, affords seasonable corroboration of our statement with regard to the agencies most likely to promote annexation. The writer represents that "while at Winnepeg, he heard of no sentiment of annexation to the United States; but," he adds, "commercial relations and railroads will effect a change in that respect."

Gen. STONE, with his baud of Americans for service in the army of the Khedive, recently passed through Paris on his way to Egypt. It is very probable that the arrival of this force may have no slight effect upon the future policy of ISMAIL PASHA. He has only been waiting for a fit opportunity to test the question whether the Sultan is to remain master of the situation or not.

JAMES GASSNER, who applied to be discharged on habeas corpus from imprisonment for non-payment of military flues, was set free by Judge CARDOZO yesterday. The act of March 17, 1870, does not aid the respondent, because section 214 confines itself to proceedings to enforce the collection of fines and penalties imposed by "any Court-material authorized by that act."

A Philadelphia express train, going east this morning, plunged into an emigrant train going west, which was standing at Leaman-place. From the dispatch of our Washington correspondent this morning, it will be seen that a proposition has been laid before the Spanish Cortes for the emancipation of slaves in Cuba. This has been done at the instigation of "loyal" Cubans. The scheme embraced is one of gradual emanicpation--all slaves born after the revolution in Spain of 1868 to be declared free at once, as well as slaves upward of sixty-five years of age.

The movement of the reserve of the old crop at the West has thus been stimulated, and an estimate of the new crop has been made, showing that a bountiful harvest may reasonably be expected.

A novel method of supplying locomotives with water while in motion, which has been for some time in use in England, is about to be introduced in this country. It has already been experimented on by the Hudson River Railroad Company, and with the greatest success.

The division in the " Left" in the Corps Legislatif is complete.

The Cunard steam-ship Tripoli, from Liverpool for Boston, in attempting to make this harbor ran ashore, at 11 o'clock this forenoon, on the rocks off Cohasset. She lies about two miles from the beach. She leaks some in her forward compartments, but has as yet received no serious injury. The passengers are all safe on board.

The debate of the question of electing a King began in the Cortes yesterday. It opens with animation, and bids fair to become exciting. The most prominent among the speakers yesterday was Senior RIVERO. He created a marked sensation by declaring that the restoration of the BOURBONS in Spain would never be permitted by the majority.

On Monday a young lady, named CARRIE JONES, attending the oak Hill Seminary, about two miles from Unionville, N.Y., at which place she also boarded, attempted to commit suicide by taking a dose of corrosive sublimate. To the Editor of the New-York Times: Prof. JOSEPH HENRY, Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, in his recent letter of "instructions for the erection of lightning-rods," describes substantially the old-fashioned round iron rod of eighty years ago, which, he says, "may be put up by an ordinary blacksmith," and which accords with his "latest knowledge of all the facts of electricity."

Early yesterday morning a fire was discovered in the stable of MICHAEL SANFORD, on Hill-street, Nowar. Owing to the inflammable nature of theframe building, and the want of an adequate supply of water, the flames quickly communicated to the methodist Protestant Church, but through the efforts of the firemen, were confined to the windows and roofs.

The failure of JAMES BOYD, a few days ago, has had its effect upon the gold and stock markets, in consequence of sales of his contracts under the rule. KETCHUM has not been seen since Thursday morning, and it is presumed he has retired to his country-seat on the Hudson.

WORDSWORTH'S poetical query of " which way does the wind come which way does it blow ?" has just now a very practical significance for us Now-Yorkers sweltering in a temperature which yesterday reached 98? in the shade.

Gen. SHERIDAN. who returned to his head-quarters, last night, from a tour through the Indian Country, has been absent since the 3d of May. During his trip he has traveld over 5,000 miles. The most distant point visited was Fort Benton.

A desperate conflict took place in Hollis, Peoria County, yesterday afternoon. in which pistols, knives, pitchforks, clubs, , were used. Nine persons were seriously, and perhaps fatally wounded. The battle took place in a harvest-field, and had its origin inn an old grudge.

Ex-Queen ISABELLA of Spain. it is reported was, yesterday, in Paris, to sign her solomn abdication....NAPGLEON, it is stated, had another attack of pheumatism, yesterday, induced by a change in the weather....LEDRU ROLLIN and also the Chinese Embassy have arrived in Paris.

The meeting was called by the President of the Quarantine Commission, pursuant to a request by the Committee of Merchants.

The nomination of Mr. ALONZO G. A conference of the representatives of four "nations" of Indians was held recently at the town of Okmulgee, situated on the prairies, about fifty miles south-west of Fort Gibson. The tribes represented wore the Cherokees, Creeks or Muscogeos, Seminoles, and Osages.

LONDON, June 27.--The Earl of CLARENDON died, quite suddenly, yesterday. He was seventy years old. NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 5.--President GRANT closes his visit to the land of his ancestors and of steady habits to-night. He has been four days in Counecticut, during which he has traveled through a good portion of the State, and has shaken hands with a good portion of its inhabitants. He has listened quietly to innumerable speeches, but has adhered to his uniform habit of making very few in return.

An old German woman of seventy years, named BERTHA DARING, made a desperate attempt to commit suicide in the Ohio River, opposite the Little Miami depot, at 11 o'clok today. The Directors of the Canada Air-Line Railroad Company met today. The whole amount of stock was subscribed, and the necessary deposit made to their credit with the Provincial Treasurer. The plans and specifications are announced for the 2d of September, on which tenders will be accepted.

The law in Great Britain in reference to the property of married women has long been condemned as cruel and unjust. The idea upon which it is really based is that a wife is a mere chattel, having no right of possession over property of any description which she may have acquired-not even to the wages she may earn for her own support, in the absence of proper provision made for her by her husband.

Judging from the result of yesterday's proceedings. there is little chance of the Fleetwood Park management ever becoming popular with the New-York public, for a more barefaced and studied ignoring of the comfort and convenience of the hundreds who visited this so-called model trotting track could not possibly have occurred.

Sunday-school excursions are again becoming popular, in this vicinity, a larger number having occurred this season than for many years past.

The watering-place season may now be said to have fairly begun, but with certain differences from former years. From almost every popular Summer resort comes the same announcement, that the hotels are very slowly filling up, and that the number of cottages is increasing.

The conservative members of the Legislature in caucus this evening appointed a State Central Committee and chose RALEIGH T. DANIEL, of Richmond, as Chairman. Some opposition was made to Mr. DANIEL, on account of his supposed ultra Democratic views.

The recent parade of the First Division, on the Fourth of July, which was fully described in the TIMES of the 5th, has caused considerable comment, in consequence of the unusual delay observed in setting the column in motion, In olden times these delays, vexatious and fatiguing as they were, happened so frequently that the National Guard and the citizens were fain to believe them unavoidable.

The news from Washington, that the Committee on Commerce have reported favorably on Mr. MURPHY'S appointment. will not astonish our readers. We stated on Thursday that Mr. CONKLING had made his arrangements too well to be disappointed.

A general strike among the operatives at Millhouse, a city near Strasbourg, occurred today. This city is one of the most important manufacturing centers in France. According to some accounts the strikers number 60,000. The Government has sent a body of troops there to prevent disorder.

The Normal College, of this City, was an institution greatly needed for years before it was established. Our public school system had been suffering from a want of trained and compotent teachers, more especially in the primary departments. The Board of Education, therefore, about one year ago, took measures to found the institution. which is destined to prove to be such a great auxiliary to our educational system.

Prince ARTHUR'S farewell speech at Quebec on his departure from Canada for England, last Tuesday, was in full as follows: GENTLEMEN: Your expressions of goodwill and affectionate interest in all that concerns my future welfare and usefulness in the career which, by God's will may be before me, are such as to demand a most cordial response on my part, and most sincerely do I offer to you my heartfelt thanks.

Judge BRADY, at the Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday heard a motion to dissolve an injunction in the suit of JOHN NYCE vs. The Erie Railway Company. The injunction was granted in April last, ex parte, restraining Messrs. RAPHAEL, HEATH CO., who are large holders of Eric stock, from procuring its transfer upon the hooks of the Erie Company, and also restraining the corporation from permitting such transfer.

The Custom-house was a scene or confusion during the greater part of yesterday. Morn bearing faces strange to the habitues of the granite building were peering about, evidently in search of some one, and disappointed at not discovering the object of their search. After looking about for a little, and peeping timidly into the Collector's room, they retired and gave place to another squad, who would go through about the same movements.

The telegraph brings us tidings of the sudden death of Rear-Admiral JOHN A. DAHLGREN, which took place at his quarters at the Washington Navy-yard yesterday morning. He had been unwell for a day or two, but not sufficiently so to excite any alarm. Shortly after rising, and while engaged in dressing, he fell, and almost immediately expired.

An extensive and bloody riot occurred yesterday afternoon in Elm Park, near Eight-avenue and Ninetieth-street, between the members of the American Protestant Association, or Orangemen, and a mob of Irish laborers from the Boulevard, the result being that three men were killed outright, several fatally and over one hundred seriously wounded.

The Fenian trial was resumed this morning at 9 o'clock. The District-Attorney called PATRICK LEAHY, of Trout River. Gen. STARR occupied a room in his house on the 26th. The witness not having arrived, Gen. STARR asked permission to testify on his own behalf.

Some of the plans for the improvement of our water-front provide for the construction of double tracks over the landward end of the piers, on which passenger-trains, drawn by steam, may be run as often as the necessities of the traveling public require.

Work upon the Hell Gate obstructions has temporarily ceased, owing to an exhaustion of the funds appropriated by Congress for the purpose. An additional appropriation of $250,000 has been made within a few days, but as no official notification of the fact has reached Gen. NEWTON, of the Engineer Corps, no steps have been taken to renew operations.

Public opinion and a majority of the French journals are opposed to accepting the dispatch of the father of Prince HOHENZOLLERN to the Spanish Government as a final settlement of the question between France and Prussia. Most of the journals assert that the Ministers went so far in their declarations that peace without a direct acknowledgement on the part of Prussia would be more a shame than a success for France.

The Tudar Company's building, at the end of Charles River Bridge, Charlestown, was completely destroyed by fire early this evening. The fire was caused by friction of the machinery. The building was used as a manufactory of linseed-oil in the lower part, and jute-bagging in the upper part.

The steam-boat Right Way exploded this morning near Thibadeaux, Bayou La Fourche. She sunk almost imdiately. Killed--LEON COMEAUX, of Assumption, bar-keeper; MIKE SMITH, of St. Louis.First Engineer. and seven colored deck hands.

The investigation was witnessed by a large gathering from the up-town wards, the spectators being very orderlyand quiet.

The working men made a demonstration yesterday. They marched through the streets, bearing banners on which were written, "The people are dying of hunger." In front of the Ministry of the Interior and other public Departments they halted and demanded employment. Their conduct was orderly, and the manifestation ended without disturbance.

The fall of one per cent. in British console yesterday, shows how fast the opinion is gaining ground that England is doomed to be drawn into the present war. We have from the first pointed out the apparent impossibility of Great Britain remaining a more spectator of a contest in which the destinies of all Europe are largely involved.

The entries for the August meeting of the Buffalo Driving Park Association closed last night, with the exception of those for the double team race, which will remain open until the 6th of August. Notwithstanding the largely increased premiums this year, the entrance fees come nearer covering the premiums than any previous year.

The Cleveland Boiler Plate Company's rolling mill was destroyed by fire last night. The loss is estimated at $30,000 to $.50,000. The fire is supposed to have caught from a spark from a locomotive. BOSTON, Mass., July 24.-The trouble for some time past existing between the shoe manufacturers and the St. Crispins of Lynn has been settled satisfactorily to all parties, and work will be resumed on Monday.

The will of the late GEORGE W. WHISTLER, the American railway engineer, who died here several months ago leaving property to the amount of [Pound]100,000, was proven last week. WILLIAM W. APPLETON, of Boston, nephew of the deceased, is one of the executors of the will.

Last night, about 9 o'clock, a difficulty occurred at GRIFFIN WALKER'8 saloon, between, Capt. JOHN M. ANDERSON, of Monroe County, and WILLIAM DOZIER, of this city, resulting fatally to the latter. DOZIER had been drinking pretty freely, and early in the evening had seen ANDERSON in the bar-room, whom he insulted.

The sight of a tea garden in the daytime is, on the whole, rather depressing to the spirits. The aspect of Highbury Barn during the afternoon of yesterday was, however, not taken into account by the visitors who came to see the baby show, so extensively advertised by the proprietor.

A report, fully credited by those best informed, has reached the city, that Mr. JOHN R. TAYLOR, well known here, recently committed suicide by drowning himself in one of the far Western rivers. The desperate deed was done, it is said, a few days after the receipt of the news that a divorce had been granted his wife. If so, it is the said ending of a painfully-checkered career.

Thousands of New-York Teutons and Hibernians emigrated to the city of bountiful lager, yesterday, to quaff the cooling and inviting beverage unrest gained by the prying eyes of inquisitive M. P.s, and revel in the shady retreats of the Elysian Fields and the Otto Gardens.

During the thunder-storm on Saturday afternoon, the stable of EDWIN HUBBEL, connected with the brick-yard at Coxsackie. was set on fire by lightning and to-tally destroyed with its contents, including tow horses and a quantity of hay and grain. Loss, $4,000.

The past week, like the one preceding, has been unprecedentedly dull. At the Exchange but one sale of City property has been made, that by ROBERTS MCGUIRE, on Thursday, of two lots on One Hundred and Twenty-ninth-street for $7,300.

The severe trials incident to the Summer season. in the lives of the working classes, cannot be even faintly appreciated by those who simply look on. To know truly what the man or woman dependent upon their daily toil for the maintenance of themselves, (and, it may be, a large household also.) suffers, one must be of the toilers themselves.

On Saturday night DANIEL NEIL and his wife, CATHARINE, drank to excess in their apartment, in the attic of No. 455 Greenwich-street, and finally quarreled. They retired at length. Early yesterday morning NEIL called at the apartment of a neighbor and borrowed a light. Soon afterward he came out and declared his wife was dead.

Soon after 11 o'clock last night, a fire was discovered on the rear of the extensive building, Nos. 71 and 73 Broadway, and extending nearly 200 beet down Rector-street. The entire fifth floor is occupied by the American Bank Note Company. The tire was first discovered in the drying-room.

This is one of the cleverest novels of the season, and it is also one of the best Mr. WILKIE COLLINS has ever written. Man and Wife is constructed with marvelous ingenuity, and it is a novel of the sort that tempts people to finish the whole at a single sitting. Many of the characters, too, are made to live and move in a way that pertains to the highest art in fiction.

Some time last November a draft for $1,000, belonging to Mr. KELLER, of Capon Forge, was stolen from the mail by some one, and sent to New-York to be called. For it two notes of $500 each were returned, and these were also taken from the mail.

On Tuesday last a negro came into the city from Linn's Ranch, on the Medina, and reported that a young woman had died there under very singular circumstances several days before. As foul play of some kind was suspected, a jury was summoned to go out and bold an inquest on the body.

WM. LYONS, of No. 28 Summit-street, Brooklyn, yesterday called on has affianced, RACHEL DORSEY, at No. 1,007 Second-avenue. They quarreled, and she returned him the engagement ring. Disappointed and enraged, he Swallowed a quantity of laudanum, with the in tention of ending his life. He was reomved to Belleveu Hospital, and is now in a precarious condition.

The murderer, VENDRUTH D. WASHBURN, passes his time in reading novels. He does not seem to realize the position he is in, and says he has no fears of that " thing arouud his neck that chekes a feller to death." From a gentleman direct from Boston, I learn the full and correct particulars of the fatal affair.

A Coblentz dispatch of yesterday says that a Prussian force from Saartouls, which crossed the French border on Saturday to reconnoiter in the direction of St. Avoid and Metz, encountered an outpost of French troops, and after a brisk skirmish retired, leaving two men on the field. The French loss is set at ten or twelve killed.

There are romantic events even in the records of this matter-of-fact age, and one such is now in progress in the picturesque forest of Bondy, It is said that in the year 1793, an immense treasure, consisting of precious stones for the most part, was carried off from Meridon-where the Emperor NAPOLEON now has a private gun manufactory-and buried in this wood.

In these latter days, when the red cloud of war has burst o'er "Fair Bingen on the Rhine," the end whereof the wisest statesmen admit their inability to foresee, it is a positive relief to human anxiety to find a man who, as the authorized expositor of the inscrutable ways of Providence, can see and show us the end from the beginning.

We learn from the officers of the steamer Ben Franklin that the storm that visited our city last evening raged with great violence, on the river between here and Madison, Ind., doing great damage to property and causing the loss of several lives. Two horses at Rising Sun, Ind., were struck by the lighting, which also paid its attentions to Carrollton.

As a very faint prelude to the coming storm, we have news from the probable seat of war of a skirmish on Saturday between a reconnoitering party from the Prussian fortress of Saarlouis, and a body of French Chasseurs-the light cavalry of the Empire. The two dispatches received evidently relate to the same event.

It may not be generally known that there are half a dozen dress-making establishments in this City, where the sewing upon dresses is almost entirely performed by men. The chief of these is in an up-town street, near Broadway, but as there are no indications of masculine surroundings in the reception-rooms, ladies who call to give orders rarely know the source of their dainty adornments.

Many circumstances during late years have tended to increase our knowledge of China and the Chinese. We have become acquainted with much of their social life, their curious theology is more familiar, and the general condition and culture of the people are better understood than was the case not many years ago.

Yesterday being Sunday, everybody who takes an interest in the ocean yacht-race availed themselves of the day of leisure to go down the Bay, expecting, doubtless, that the yachts would be so accommodating as to arrive while they were on hand to welcome them.

The college is now in a most flourishing condition. Notwithstanding the fact that the class graduated this year is somewhat smaller than that of former years, the large size of the lower classes fully makes up the deficiency.

The discovery of a secret treaty between two European Powers against the integrity of other Powers must always cause a painful sensation, but the particular document published yesterday is something without parallel in the history of intrigue. The story is that a treaty was discussed between France and Prussia, by virtue of which France recognized the acquisitions of Prussia from Austria, and agreed to the union of the North and South German States, Austria excepted.

The Journal Officiel, this morning, contains a decree nominating the Viscount J. DE TREILHARD, at present Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to Chili, as French Minister to Washington, vice M. PREVOST PARADOL, deceased.

During the approaching contest between France and Prussia it will be interesting to note what influence the improved arms of the combatants have in determining the final issue. In previous wars, one side or the other has often gained the advantage from the superiority of its armament, but never before did two armies enter the field so thoroughly furnished with improved and deadly weapons.

The distressing beat continued yesterday, and is having serious effect on the lives of the citizens. Heretofore the deaths have been confined to old men and young children, but from the returns of yesterday will be perceived that young and middle-aged men are falling victims to the sudden mortality.

The damage to the works of the Meriden Britannia Company, of Meriden, Conn., by the fire of July 16, seems to have been scarcely so great as was at first reported. The three upper floors only of the main building were destroyed and the loss of machinery, shafting, , in them, was pretty heavy; but it is very much less than the insurance, and the work of rebuilding will be commenced immediately.

The spectacle was a fearful, yet a sub. lime one to the merest spectator; but to those who were ruthlessly driven from their workshops, places of business and residences, with hardly a moment's warning, it meant desolation and suffering.

The trial of DENNIS McGROTTY for the homicide of ROBERT HARTMAN, on the night of the 2d of May last, at Lafayette, Jersey City,was continued yesterday in the Hudson County Court, before Judge BEDLE and two associates. The Court-room was well filled, principally with the friends of the prisoner.

The match between the picked nine of the leading Brooklyn Clubs and the Atlantic nine, arranged to be played, yesterday, on the Capitoline Grounds for the benefit of the widow and children of the late Mr. PICCOT, took place according to announcement. and it proved to be quite a fine display of the beauties of the game by the Atlantics,

A regular meeting of the Seventh Assembly District Republican Association was held, last evening, at No. 815 Broadway. Owing to the absence of both the President and VicePresident of the organization, Col. A. J. H. DUGANNE was called to the chair.

The woolen-mill of JOHN DEARIE, near Fairmont, was destroyed by fire this morning, causing a loss of $60,000. The fire originated in the picker-room. Two hundred persons were thrown out of employment. There was $24,000 insurance on the mill. Two or three dwellings adjoining were damaged.

It is reported that the National Stock Exchange is in the throes of dissolution, and that it will no longer throw obstacles in the way of the exclusive dealing in stocks which has been enjoyed by the New-York Stock Exchange. This institution was organized some two years ago, at the time when Erie was thrown out of the New-York Stock Board, and was then known as the Erie Exchange.

A case which comes up today in the Supreme Court Chambers, before Judge BRADY. presents a most revolting aspect of City life, and lays bare a state of facts scarcely credible. The following statement was obtained from the father of one of the interested parties: Three years ago a certain gentleman and his wife lived happily at No. 79 Cannon-street, in this City.

The Troy Press, of July 25, says: During the storm, Saturday morning, a boy named CHAS. SNYDER, aged six years, whose parents live at No. 442 Madison-avenue, Albany, was killed by lightning, on the walk, corner of Madison-avenue and Snipe-street. His brother, who accompanied him, was knocked down by the same flash.

JOHN GALLAGHER and his wife were found dead in bed this morning in a tenement-house on Swasson street, in the Third Ward. There were no marks of violence on the bodies, and it is supposed that they died from intemperance, and that their death was hastened by the heat of the weather.

Coroner BATHGATE held an inquest at Morrisania, yesterday, on the remains of an unknown man, who was run over by an express train of the New-York and New-Haven Railroad Company, at that place, about nine o'clock A. M. It appears that the deceased was seen walking on the up-track, near Fourth-street, immediately after a train had passed down, and just then the Boston express, from New-York, was observed coming up.

At 2 1/2 o'clock yesterday afternoon a lire broke out at No. 172 Washington-street, originating on the third floor, and causing a loss of nearly $25,000, as follows: First floor, occupied by F. Gaylord, liquor-dealer; $500 by water, and by T. M. Burney, about $500 by water; insured for $1,000 each.

MARGARET FIELDING, of Albany, lately stopping at No. 13 Morris-street, made an affidavit, yesterday afternoon, at the Tombs, before Justice HOGAN, charging that GEORGE BYRNE, one of the attaches of the City Hall, had outraged her in the Chamber of the Board of Assistant Aldermen, at the City Hall.

The Allegheny Park was the scene of a rather singular episode on Saturday evening. A few minutes before 7 o'clock, a young woman, neatly arrayed in black clothing, and of a prepossessing appearance, entered the mclosure east of Federal-street, and took one of the ladies' seats, not far from the entrance. There was an air of mystery about the female's movements which attracted the attention of some young men who were setting near by.

Mr. BOYD, counsel for School Commissioner HENNESSY, recently expelled his office on being found guilty of having taken a bribe for the appointment of a female teacher, made an application to Judge BRADY, sitting at Supreme Court Chambers, yesterday, for a writ of mandamus to compel the Board of Education to reinstate Mr. HENNESSY in the office from which he had been expelled.

The Japanese gentlemen, who are now engaged at Crosby's Opera-house in the legitimate exercise of a respectable calling, will probably carry with them from Chicago a rather poor estimate of the courtesy of its inhabitants. One member of the troupe, at least, will have reason to remember his visit, very much as Stephen, the martyr, if he had lived through it, would have remembered his visit to Jerusalem.

The Fall River News says on Friday, while Mrs. AMY GRINNELL and another woman, with some children, were driving along the Fish road, near the Cook pond, a man who was sitting on the wall stepped up and stopped their team, and turned to Mrs. GRINNELL with the demand-- "Your money or your life." She took out her pocket-book and threw a dollar on the grass, saying that was all she had.

The new arrangement adopted by the merchants for evading the exactions of the NewYork Quarantine offcials, by discharging their vessels at Perth Amboy, N. J., works charmingly, and the coffee dealers especially are delighted with their success.

We printed on Monday an account from a London correspondent of the memorable sale, on the 9th inst., of some of Mr. DICKENS' pictures and other personal effects. It is gratifying to know that the prices realized were very high. The affection and respect for the great novelist that are thus indicated, even although in a material way, are pleasant to see and to record.

BERKING.--At Newark, N. J., on the 25th inst., GRACE M. A., infant daughter of Charles H. and Pauline C. Berking, aged 8 months and 16 days. Funeral services at the parents' residence, corner of Fairmount and South Orange avs., on Friday, July 29, at 10 o'clock A. M. Relatives and friends are invited to attend. Interment in Green-Wood Cemetery.

When, three weeks ago, we were commemorating with enthusiasm the declaration of our national independence, our Minister at the Court of Vienna was celebrating, by the time-honored formula of a dinner, the same glorious anniversary.

The Society of American Philologists organized and inaugurated qy the first scholars of the country, met in this city this afternoon and will remain in session the whole week. A local committee of distinguished citizens.

About 9 o'clock last evening the passenger train from Chicago, which arrives in Toledo in the morning ran into a hand-carthree miles west of South Bend, and killed three men. One of the, killed was the section foreman of the Western Division of the L. S. and M. S. Railway, and the other two were wood-choppers.

The apparent destiny of the Island is at present undergoing a remarkable change. The Cubans have great expectations on the fact that the slavery question will bring them the aid of the Abolition Party in the United States and Europe, and that of the negroes themselves.

I remember once witnessing in London, in a scolding match between two burly coal-porters who flourished their fists in a manner to make the by-standers apprehend a sanguinary set-to. The scolding, however, lasted too long, and the flourishing was too theatrical not to convince me speedily that neither of the men had any earnest stomach for a fight.

The Sabbath-schools of Christ (Lutheran) Chruch and St. Stephen's (Lutheran) Church of this City, and St. Matthew's (Lutheran) Church, Brooklyn, went on a general excursion and picnic Monday on the steamer Josephine to Alderney Park.

A special dispatch from Strasbourg, received today, says that the elite of the French Army is now concentrated at Strasbourg and Belfort. The A1gerian forces, consisting of Zouaves and Turcos, and filling eighteen railway trains, reached Strasbourg on the 24tb, and today took up their position at Belfort, close to the Baden line.

It seems that the Mormons are likely to be the largest gainers by the provision in the new Tax, that in the assessment of the joint income of any religious community, each five members shall be held to constitute a family, and be entitled to the exemption of $1,000.

A dispatch from Austin, dated the 25th, says reports from the frontier detail a new series of outrages in the country occupied by the Indians. Horses are carried off by droves, and scores of families are abandoning their homes, and in many instances reduced to destitution.

Tho location of the camp-meeting rounds of the East New-York M. E. Conference is at Merrick, L. I., at one of the most beautiful spots in the State of New-York, distant about twenty-two miles from New-York City and about one and a half miles from the south beach of the island. The South-side Railroad from Grand and Roosevelt street ferries runs within about ton minutes' walk of the grounds.

It is quite certain that the people of NewYork will not always tamely submit to the outrageous treatment they at present receive from the gas companies. If we were not the most patient community under the sun--the most inclined of any people to allow any sort of extortion and sharp dealing to be practiced upon us--we should long ago have delivered ourselves from many evils under which we groan.

The ranama and West India Cable Company have employed two lighters, and have commenced the landing of the chore end of the cable at Batabano- Ten tons of cable have been embarked on the lighters, and is being paid out across the shallow place between the Suffolk's anchorage and the town of Batabano.

Savings Bank managers might usefully reconsider the rule by which the allowance of interest on deposits dates from periods between which there are long intervals. Some of these institutions pay no interest on deposits which have not remained six months,--the more liberal limiting the period to three months.

The French Government has addressed a diplomatic note to the Spanish Cabinet, which gave rise to a long discussion at the last Council of Ministers, presided over by the Regent. If I am rightly informed, the Regent, in the course of this sitting, stated that he now saw all the complicated difficulties which he had anticipated from the German candidature gradually realizing themselves.

The officers of the gallant New-York Seventh, cherishing a lively and agreeable recollection of the cordial greeting which they received on their recent excursion at Philadelphia, have, ever since their return, been anxiously hoping for an opportunity to at least partially acknowledge, in suitable form, the generous hospitality of which they had been the recipients.

The excitement in England, occasioned by the publication of the secret treaty between France and Prussia, continues to increase. Nearly all the journals of yesterday treat the matter as fact proved, and the Times says "France must explain this offensive treaty." It is the opinion of many that the treaty will be made a pretext for intervention in favor of England.

We also stated that there was little doubt that he had previously poisoned her step-daughter to death, and had made attempts on the life of her husband, who was lying ill at the time of her death.

It seems almost incredible that two yachts should get out into the broad Atlantic to run a race, and after an interval of twenty-four days make their appearance at a given point within two hours of each other. The accident of either competitor catching a lucky breeze an hour or two earlier than the other would be all that was required to decide so extraordinary a race as this.

There seems to be some trouble brewing among. the officials at the Lehigh and Susquehanna Railroad shops at Nanticoke Junction. The directors are looking into the doings of Mr. BRASTOW, and a majority of the officials, against whom charges have been preferred, and although no changes have as yet been made, it is quite probable that there will be some very se material ones made.

Revolutionary intrigue is rife in Rome and Italy, in view of the probable withdrawal of the French troops. A secret deposit of arms has been discovered in Genoa, and a large quantity of guns and ammunition seized by the Government.

Commissioner BRENNAN was called upon yesterday, to dispose of a heavy calendar of fifty-three cases, as a consequence of the activity of the general roundsmen in detecting petty derelictions, and many of them were of such very flimsy character that they were dismissed with no more serious result to the offender than a reprimand.

It is impossible to observe without regret, not wholly unmixed with shame, the statements which come day after day from North Carolina. That outrages of the most shocking character have been perpetrated with impunity in some parts of that State, is a fact which, unfortunately, admits of no dispute.

Revenue Officers BROOKS and CLARKE, accompanied by Deputy Marshals and members of the secret service department, the whole making a force of thirteen men, paid an early visit, yesterday morning, to the old Richmond district, reaching the point from which it was designed to commence operations about four o'clock.

The annual meeting of the Grand Army of the Republic convened here today. Some ten or twelve contestants for the prizes were entered for the tub-race on Saturday afternoon. The race took place in the cove in front of the Brown Cotton Gin Works. Those contesting were all employes of that Company. A large crowd assembled to witness the performance, which commenced at 5 o'clock.

The Democratic journals despise the excellent advice of the venerable Mrs. Glasse. They are counting the gains of victory before victory has been achieved. They are confident that their party will receive large accessions of strength from the Fall elections, and tell in advance the complexion of the new House of Representatives.

The Panama and West. India Cable Company's steamer, Saffolk, sailed from Batabano this morning to lay the cable to Cayo Juan-Rinz, at which place she will unite it with the twenty-five miles already laid across the keys. The steamer Dacia will sail from Cienfuegos and connect the other end with Cayo Diego-Perez.

The long agony about the great international ocean yacht-race is now over, and the result, although unhoped for and unlooked for by Americans generally, is one which reflects credit on the sailing powers and management of the Dauntless, while adding, at the same time, another to the many triumphs secured by the English yacht Cambria.

Parliament is still at work upon its financial scheme, and a languid progress is made, to which the heat of the season does not give any new stimulus. There is talk of an adjournment, which will probably come within a month. But before it takes place the contract with the bank, the most important measure of the session, win become a law, and the treasury check will be replenished.

The jury who retired at 6 o'clock on 'Tuesday evening to deliberate on a verdict in the case of DENNIS MCGROTTY, indicted for the murder of ROBERT HARTMAN at Lafayette, Jersey City, reported at 10 o'clock yesterday morning after being out sixteen hours.

A French journalist, M. BERTRAND, has discovered a new trade, which he says is carried on in London. It is the delight of many Parisians to detect fresh and heinous sins in the British capital, which, through the pens of its writers, has so long flaunted virtuous indignation before the eyes of naughty Paris.
A dispatch from Heart's Content, N. F., dated at 3 1/2 P. M. today, announces that the fault in one of the Atlantic cables near this harbor was Depaired at noon.

The guests were playing at cards yesterday evening in Gen. PRIM'S reception-rooms, when, at about 10 1/2 o'clock, a dispatch was handed to him. This informed him that the father of Prince LEOPOLD of Hohenzollern refused the Crown of Spain for his son, because, notwithstanding his willingness to accept it, the opposition which had been raised against his candidature would in all probability lead to a general war.

Details of the movements of the hostile armies on the French and Prussian frontier continue to be meager and unimportant. Capt. JOHN J. MONAHAN was arraigned before the United States Circuit Court today, for violating the Neutrality laws, and leaded guilty. Gen. O'NEIL was then placed in the dock, and asked by tile Court if he had anything to say why the sentence of the Court should not be passed upon him.

The agent of the Executive Committee apointed at the St. Louis Convention for devising means to secure the removal of the national capital, has secured Pike's Hall, in this City, for the Convention, which will be hold on Oct. 25, 1870.

The Fifth Maryland Regiment arrived from Cape May about 11 o'clock this morning. They were received by the National Guards and escorted to Franklin-square, where, .after stacking arms, they were conducted to the National Guards' Hall in the vicinity, and partook of a banquet.

One of the most surprising circumstances connected with modern London is its rapid growth. We are very apt to dwell with astonishment upon the wonderful expansion of our own City, and to indulge in great anticipations of the future; but we doubt if New-York has increased, in population or extent, during the last thirty years, as much in proportion as London.

The forty-first annual meeting of the American Institute of Instruction began its session yesterday morning at 11 o'clock, in Washburn Hall, there being a rather small attendance, about 150 persons, at the opening. Prof. S. S. GREENE, of Brown University, President of the Association. Called the meeting to order, and Rev. T. E. ST. JOHN Made the opening prayer, after which Mayor BLAKE made the address of welcome in behalf of the citizens.

About 2 o'clock P. M., yesterday, a branch sower now being excavated in the upper end of Broad-street, Newark, near the Morris and Essex Railroad Depot, caved in without warning, and buried two men out of sight. The sower was about twenty feet deep, was boarded up with spruce planking, braced by cedar cross pieces at intervals of about four feet.

The Methodists of Marquette, Mich., are to have a new church, to cost $10,000. BISHOP BAKER, of the Methodist Church, is still in poor health. There are 1,352 Wesleyan Methodist local preachers in Australia and New-Zealand. East Tennessee congratulates itself on the possession of 30,000 Baptists.

It is evident that the dastardly murder of BENJAMIN NATHAN is not to be hold as a day's wonder, and then allowed to be shelved away among the blood-stained records of the past. The community has been too deeply stirred by the awful crime to permit it to be the prey of dumb forgetfulness, and the public feeling is none the less deep and earnest because undemonstrative, as it certainly was yesterday.

The man who murdered Mr. NATHAN, on Thursday night, or early on Friday morniug, is, in all human probability, still in New-York, and doubtless reads the papers as regularly as anyone else. He is, very likely, much amused with the reporters' very positive statements about him, and knows but too well the value of the " clues" which are said to have been obtained.

And one has, without overstepping the bounds of official inquiry, every day forced upon his observation much of the interior workings of society,

Since the organization of te Department of Parks, energetic measures have been in progress to beautify some of the public parks and render them, in some respects at least, ornaments of the Metropolis. With a single exceptiou, no very great changes can be chronicled in the appearance of the different squares, the maxim applied by the Department in the majority of cases being apparently "here a little, there a little."

The Times, a few evenings since, gave publicity to a rumor which involved a Lutheran clergyman of a " neighboring town" in a scandalous transaction. The article, as printed, contained an important error. The person involved in the affair is accused of taking unusual liberties with the persons of several members of his flock, and not of seduction.

The flourishing suburb of Evanston, twelve miles north of this city, has recently been the scene of another outrage that would be a disgrace to a community of barbarians. For some reason or other, Evanston has enjoyed a special reputation for high morality and superior piety.

Assistant Alderman HENRY ROGERS died at his residence in Christopher-street at 11/2 A. M. yesterday. He had been ill for some weeks past, but the immediate cause of his death was exhaustion from excessive heat. Mr. ROGERS was highly respected by all who knew him. Three times he wits an Assemblyman from this City, and twice a member of the Board of Assistant Aldermen.

The Philadelphia Telegraph, of July 29, says: Yesterday considerable correspondence took place between the proprietors of the Pennsylvania sugar Refinery, at Crown and, Race streets, recently destroyed by fire, and the Chief of Police, relative to the removal of the insecure walls of the ruins.

Time has been when, after all the theatres and opera-houses had closed, some enterprising emulator of GREEN, WISE OF LOWE, would go up in a ballon during the dogs-days, and so furnish a topic for those who chronicle public amusements to eke out their scanty records. This season, however, not even that aerial resource is supplie us.

About 300 people, including a number of ladies, assembled at the Lake Shore Railway bridge yesterday afternoon to witness FRANK THORNE make a leap from the bridge into the creek. About 5 o'clock FRANK appeared on the upper part of the bridge, dressed in a sort of Georgia uniform--"trunks," we believe is the technical name--and was greeted with any amount of applause.

JOHN KERR and other citizens of Caswell, who wore arrested by CoL KIRK'S militia. KIRK ordered him to leave or he would have him fired on. Hon. W. W. BELKNAP, Secretary of War, and Gen. A. . DYER, Chief of Ordnance, spent yesterday at the Arsenal, and last night took the train at Albany for Springfield. The Secretary is on a tour of inspection and observation, and will visit a number of arsenals and armories before returning to Washington.

She has long been a practicing physician, and in Illinois, at least, she is only prevented from being a practicing lawyer by the unchivalric conservatism of the Courts.

It is the dullest time of the year for our City theatres. Their parquets and boxes. which were wont to swarm with life, to be radiant with bright eyes and gay colors, to echo with cheers and ringing laughter. are empty and still as so many mausoleums. Their stages. which were so lately filled with gay pictures and swiftly-moving figures, are solemn and dim as abandoned churches.

Reports to the War Department from Kansas state that white men are making unusually strong efforts to get possession of claims held by Osage Indians. supposing that when the anticipated opening of their lands to settlers is effected the Indians will be removed whether settled on colonies or not, and in that event the white man on a claim will be entitled to file papers for the same.

There are serious charges pending before the Pension Office against Congressman RODERICK R. BUTLER, of Tennessee. A strong array of evidence has been brought to convict Mr. BUTLER of fraud, if not of forgery, in pension cases with which he has occupied himself.

Rev. Dr. STARRS, Vicar-General of this Archdiocese, will lay the corner-stono of the new Church of St. Rose of Lima, at 51/2 P. M. today. He was found concealed in the office of JAMES A. FRASER, at No. 105 Barclay-street, and had appropriated a quantity of wearing apparel. Popular history gives the credit, (if it be a credit,) of having first introduced the use of tobacco into Europe, to Sir WALTER RALEIGH, who, about three hundred years ago, took back to England, from Virginia, a cargo of tobacco and potatoes, as specimens of the vegetable productions he had found in New World.

Mr. POTTER PALMER and Miss BERTHA HONORE were married on last evening at 6 o'clock. They departed for New-York on the 9 o'clock express, and will make a brief tour in Europe before their return to Chicago. If weather signs are omens of good fortune surely the wedded life of Mr. and Mrs. PALMER and joyful.

A sewer in course of construction in Broad-street, near the Morris and Essex Railroad depot, caved in today, burying three laborers. A large force of reserves were immeniately set to work and two of the men were rescued alive. It is feared the other man Cannot be reached in time to save his life.

Since the official notification of the appropriation for the removal of obstructions in New-York Harbor, there has been renewed alacrity at the Government works at Hell Gate. The Republican State Committee has a six hours' session at Congress Hall, today. A State Convention is called to meet as Saratoga Springs on the 7th of September. HAMILTON HARRIS was appointed to prepare an address to published with the call, whish is the same in terms as the one issued last year.

The records of the Board of Health for last week showed an excess of 351 deaths over the corresponding period of last year. This increase is more than accounted for by the further statement that 340 children under two years of age died from Summer complaint, and eighty-five persons from sun-stroke, or the direct effects of heat.

During the present week extensive fires have been raging in the pine forests and swamps in Ocean County, N.J., near Toms River. According to the report of a correspondent well acquainted with the region of which portions were swept by the conflagration, the fire has occasioned severe losses to a large number of land-owners, and has been the most disastrous that has occurred in the county for many years.

A deputation from New??oundland waited on the Earl of KIMBERLEY, yesterday, and asked that the British troops now in the Province be suffered to remain as a protection against a possible Fenian attack.
The Coterie Montefiore gave a grand concert and Summer-night's festival at Terrace Garden, corner of Third-avenue aud Fiftyeighth-street, last evening.

Information has been received that BIG HORSE, the Cheyenne Chief, with over twenty lodges, will be at the Agency in a few days; also, that BIG JAKE will soon follow, with all he may induce to accompany him.

It will be remembered that some time during last Winter a murder was committed in Maury County in circumstances that excited considerable indignation and comment. The perpetrators of the deed, were published at the time. The name of the man killed was HENRY or HAL RAY, and the party who committed the act was a negro named DICK CUNNINGHAM.

The importance of the French victory at Saarbuck, it is claimed is due much to the fact that the heights form a key to the railway approaches to Treves. Fourteen Prussian soldiers, captured in the attack, passed through Metz on Wednesday. The Prussian wounded, it is said, receive the same care as the French. During the action the French bands played the " Marseillaise."

Yesterday morning AMOS MOORE, a resident of No. 40 Monmouth-street, Jersey City, was arrested on a warrant issued by Justice ALLEN, upon the complaint of a neighbor of the former, who charged him with attempting to murder Mrs. MOORE on Wednesday evening.

On Wednesday last the Board of Health received a notice from Dr. HENRY D. GRINDLE that a child had been still-born in his lying-in asylum, at No. 120 West Twenty-sixth-street. As the doctor's business is a very peculiar one, the Board of Health sent the ease to Coroner FLYNN for investigation.

Col. THOMAS DICKENS, well known to the people of Shelby County, and whose name is familiar to the readers of the Avalanche, was way--laid on yesterday morning by some fiend, and his life destroyed, in daylight, on a public road. The whole city was shocked and astounded by the news.

A law has been voted this week supplimentary to that of several years ago, called by the clergy the Ecclesiastical Spoliation Scheme. The present law sweeps into the public Treasury what is left of property--and it is in the aggregate considerable--upon which the clergy live, and by which worship is supported.

Yesterday JOHN REAL made his final preparations for death in expiation for the murder of Officer JOHN SMEDICK, over two years ago. The family of the prisoner, consisting of his father, mother, brother, sister and some of his personal friends, spent the greater part of the day with their doomed relative.

At the Spring term of the Court of Common Pleas for Huron County, Judge PENNEWELL presiding, BENNET SCOP was convicted of the charge of murdering JACOB GOODMAN, a peddler, in whose employ he was at the time. GOODMAN was a peddler, a Jew by birth, who, from motives of good will and sympathy to one of his own faith and ancestry, gave Scop employment and pecuniary aid.

The New-Haven Palladium of Aug. 4, says: About 2 o'clock this morning an alarm of fire was sounded, which proved to be the extensive works of the Fair Haven Keg Company, corner of Ferry and Chapel streets, Fair Haven. When the fire was discovered it was under full headway, and although the firemen and citizens rallied promptly the property could not be saved.

A pathetic story of disappointment and suffering was made known at the Police station yesterday. LOUISA LOUDERMEER, a widow, with four little children, one of them sick, arrived by the late train at the Pacific Depot on Saturday night without any means or any friends.

Nothing is more natural than that reports precisely contradictory of each other should reach us concerning the efficiency of the weapons of the French and Prussian Armies. We printed on Wednesday a telegraphic dispatch epitomizing an article from the London Times, in which it is argued that the French arm, the Chassepot, on account of its fouling speedily, will prove far less effective than the needle-gun.

Mr. CHARLES LATOUR, the editor of a temperance paper called the Progress, while crossing the City Hall Park, yesterday afternoon, just as the storm came on, was knocked down by a team of horses attached to a heavy truck, which were coming along at a furious rate. Mr. LATOUR was conveyed to the Coroner's office in an insensible state, having just consciousness enough to refuse a glass of brandy which was offered as a restorative.

The Arbetter Union, (German working mon's paper of this City,) of the 3d inst., says; "Germany has not a single friend and ally among the States, and not even among the nations. An exception to this, of course, are the members of the International Labor Union, those of the Peace and Liberty League, the adherents of the woman's rights organization and the radicals generally, who are, however, in a vanishing minority everywhere.

Yesterday was the fourth day of the Long Branch Race Meeting, and, for the first time since it was inaugurated, the weather was unfavorable. The gathering clouds in the sky throughout the morning portended a storm, but this did not prevent some 3,000 votaries of racing of both sexes from patronizing the course.

Yesterday was the third day of the campmeeting at Merrick, L. I. Most of the society tents are in position, and a large majority of the families who have tents are settled. A feature of the day was the large number of carriages which brought people from the surrounding villages.

A farewell complimentary entertainment was given at the hall of the German Young Men's Christian Association, last evening, by his friends in the Association, to Mr. FREDERICK WILLIAM BLECHSCHMIDT one of the most prominent, active and efficient members, who has endeared himself to his associates not only by his disinterested and sincere devotion to the cause of reform among the German young men of the City, but also by his kind and genial nature.

There was hard fighting at Weissenburg, yesterday. The French loss was heavy, includIng many prisoners.

Bold as have been the experiments of English legislation during the past five years, it would be difficult to find among them a measure more original and comprehensive than the new Education bill which has just passed through the House of Commons. For thirty years it has been the disgrace of England that she stood alone among the progressive nations of the world in having no truly national scheme of education.

The Board of Aldermen met yesterday afternoon, Alderman THOMAS COMAN, President in the chair. There were present Aldermen Irving, Jerome, McKeever, O'Neil, Diamond, Mitchell, Slitchting, Welsh, Plunkett, Reilly and Woltman.

A thunder-storm of considerable violence prevailed in this vicinity in the latter part of the afternoon yesterday. The Hudson River Railroad track at Spuyten Duyvil was so washed away as to throw a Yonkers train from the track. No one was injured, but all the trains were delayed. The break has been repaired and the trains are running regularly again.

The Republican State Committee, which met at Saratoga, yesterday, has complied with the predominating wish of the party by fixing an early day for the assembling of the Convention. ADOLPH LUBIN, a Frenchman residing in Hoboken-avenue, in the Third Ward of Jersey City, was arrested last night, charged with an atrocious assault upon his wife. It appears that he attacked her in his house with a large jack-knife, with which he attempted to stab her.

Rev. P. M. RIGHTMEYER, who has had so much scandal for the past few weeks in the quiet village of Brunswick Centre, Rensselaer County, has addressed a letter to the Troy Times, in which he denies the charges made against him, and states that he is fully able to prove his innocence.

The monthly meeting of the Cincinnati Base-ball Club was held in Room No. 18, Catholic Institute last evening. Fully one hundred members were present. The routine business was quickly and very quietly disposed of, and then President CHAMPION arose and made a statement of the finances of the Club.

There remains very little to be said regarding the movements of Superintendent JOURDAN and the detectives yesterday in relation to the NATHAN mystery. They worked as hard as on any previous day, but if they succeeded in any way, which is very doubtful, the officers in the case kept their own counsel, us was right and proper.

At the usual weekly meeting of the Commissioners of Docks, held yesterday afternoon, all the members of the Board were present. A representative of the Long Island Steamboat Company was present, to explain the non-existence of any platform for passenger at Pier No. 24, the Superintendent of the Board having reported said pier as having no platform of the kind required at passenger landings.

GEORGE BAKER and MICHAEL WELSH were arrested in Jersey City, last evening, on a charge of having attempted to defraud an immigrant, LOUIS SCHAFFER by name, out of $208. SCHAFFER was about to sail for Europe, and was on his way to the vessel when WELSH introduced himself as a fellow-passenger.
The game between the athletic Club, of Philadelphia, and Forest City Club, of Rockford, was won by the Latter. The score was Forest City 15, Athletic 10.

HORACE BROWN, reported killed in a riot at Peekskill, Tuesday night, was only stunned. He is on the street today. He was on a spree and threatened to club his assailant who struck him down with a stone. The affair was only a drunken brawl, and the reported moulders' riot is untrue.

The announcement of the death of Admi- oth ral DAVID GLASCOE FARRAGUT, although not altogether unexpected, will be received with unfeigned grief all over the land. He was the first and only United States naval officer who attained the full rank of Admiral-a grade which was unknown in our service until it was created as an acknowledgment of the services of the greatest naval commander 'our country has produced.

Admiral FARRAGUT died, today, very peacefully, at 12 o'clock precisely, surrounded by his family and friends, at the residence of Commodore A. M. PENNOCK, at the Navy-yard. His remains will the deposited temporarily in a vault here, until this final resting-place shall be decided upon.
